Bottle  Pours black with a thin tan head.  The head leaves quickly but lacesw well.  Aroma is burnt, coffee, and chocolate.  Has a light carbonation.  The flavor is robust and roasty.  Good amounts of milk and chocolate.  Has a medium body.  The finish is good with a decent aftertaste.  A pretty good drinking beer.
chocolate, coffee, roasty, licorice, black, brown foam, medium sweetness, lightly bitter, medium body, creamy, soft carbonation, long finish,

Bottle. Medium high creamy and lasting brown head. Pitch black body. Lovely roasted malt creamy choccolate aroma. Dense roasted malt lactose cream choccolate flavor with a good deal of hops bitterness as well, resulting in an almost sour result. Low carbonation, long bitter aftertaste.

Bottle shared by plovmand. :-) 
Pours black with a small tan head. 
Aroma is roasted malt, chocolate and a hint of coffee. 
The lactose makes the flavour quite distinct but with notes of roasted malt, liquorice and coffee.

Bottle. Pitch black body with a small to medium tan head. Lots of oat and roasted malt in aroma. Caramel and sweet tobacco. The lactose is very profound in the flavour which has notes of hard roasted malt, coffee, light chocolate and some sweet tobacco. Creamy mouthfeel.

Bottle at home.
Pitch black coloured with a medium sized fast disappearing brown head.
Sweet and roasted aroma of coffee and oat with notes of coffee.
Roasted flavour of coffee, oat and dark chocolate with notes of liquorice.
Roasted finish.
Tasty.

bottle poured a dark black in color with a small but thick dark brown head. aroma has molasses, dark chocolate, roasted malt, and coffee. coats the tongue with an oily thickness and low side carbonation. flavor has medium bitterness, roast, coffee, dark chocolate, and a sweetness on the finish. I am digging the lacto thing and the body fits the beer well.

Nummy. Poured with a small fine tan head and a tiny bit of lace. Color is an opaque oily black. Aroma is very malty, roasty, toffee/burnt sugar sweet and a hint of vanilla. Ditto the taste. Extremely drinkable. Body is luscious and carbonation is good. Finish is super easy, a bit long. Solid beer. Session if youre in this kind of mood.

Another good stout from Dark Horse.  Im enjoying this series of fine brews.  This one is an easy drinking stout that is smooth on the palate and has some nice aromas and flavors of dark malts and a bit of sweetness.

UPDATED: JAN 31, 2010 Bottle (thanks to guyinchicago for this one)...  Poured black with a thin, brown head.  Aroma was mild, with a faint roast character.  Thin, light bodied and easy drinking.  Strong malt flavors with a nice, round sweetness that was supported by a chocolate nib flavor.

Black liquid with a very small brown head. Chocolate, roast, a bit of cardboard or tin or something. Im not sure of the age of this bottle, but its not really all that old. It could have had a bad cap or something, but it seems pretty close to other descriptions. A little sweet for my taste. Slightly soured roasty malt flavors. I cant really taste any hops and the flavors suffer from the mouthfeel. Fairly flat and much too thin. It has the feel of an over-aged stout.
Pours a thick slick motor oil with a dense peaty head, aroma is heavy coffee w/ some roasty chocolate, smooth and oily body with huge bitter coffee hit on finish, great full-bodied stout
Nice midnight dark color. One inch caramel head. Chocolate aroma. Chocolate caramel malty taste. Very smooth beer.

Hard not to like this if your a fan of the style. Pours like motor oil has a great  complex aroma with a deep chocolate matt sent. hops are secondary to the complex malts.  taste is a medium sweet perhaps a little maple on this. a sticky oily sensation on the palate. Over all high marks on this great brew.

12 oz. bottle from Ludlow Wines.  Pours dark, opaque brown, and looks like motor oil out of the bottle- near black in color, with a creamy brown head that isnt very thick but sticks around for quite a while.  Aroma of sweet roasted malts, dark chocolate, milk chocoalte, coffee, cream, and a hint of smoke.  Flavor follows suit well, with plenty of dark and milk chocolate, sweet cream, smoke, and roasted malts.  Medium-full bodied, with a slick, oily mouthfeel and roasty finish.  Gentle, low carbonation, and very smooth.  Tried side-by-side with the Dark Horse One, and the One edges it out, but not by much.  Great duo of beers.
This is simply a good stout!  I wouldnt necessary say a great milk stout--pretty damn dry.  But I dont care, this is still good.  Im beginning to pay more attention to Dark Horse.

Draft at South Park Tavern in Dayton, OH.  Huge roast in this creamy stout.  Pours an opaque black with minimal head and flavors of roasted malts, dark chocolate and dark roasted coffee.  At over 8 percent, the alcohol is totally hidden with classic stout complexity and flavors.
Bottle. Thanks Rciesla for sharing. Black pour with tan head. Lactose, roasted malt, and chocolate malt. Easy drinkable stout.

12oz. Bottle:  Aroma of bitter coffee, light chocolate, roasted malt, and slight lactose.  Poured pitch black in color with a large, creamy, dense, dark brown head that diminished but lasted throughout.  Opaque.  Sparkling.  Flavor is lightly sweet and light to medium bitter.  Tastes of roasted malt, bitter coffee, light chocolate, light lactose, and some Earthiness.  Medium body.  Chalky, lightly dry texture.  Average carbonation.  Roasted malt, light chocolate, and light lactose finish is chalky and dry.  8%ABV is totally hidden throughout.

One of several beers my wife got me for Christmas from beergeek.biz.  12oz bottle.  Deep black pour with two fingers dark tan head.  Roasted malt, chocolate and smoke in the aroma.  Taste is burnt chocolate, coffee, vanilla and dark fruit.  On the thin side of medium bodied with a chalky light bitter finish - comes off a slight bit watery.  Dont catch any of the 8% alcohol.  Nice drinkable sweet stout.
bottle.  Pours black with a thin, brown head which had good lacing, but dissiapted.  Nose is of chocolate and coffee.  Taste is of coffee grounds.  Mouthfeel is medium-thin and dry.
bottle courtesy of coyote hunter i believe! black pour with a nice small dark brown head. nice slightly soured lactic aroma. nice taste and body, super malty dry and a tad watery towards the end.

Another solid beer from Dark Horse.  Pours black with a thin tan head.  Aroma of cocoa, roast, and maybe some caramel.  Good flavor without being overly sweet.  Nice creamy roasted stout with solid chocolate flavor.  Well done.

Been waiting awhile to pop the top on this one, so early on Christmas eve...about to get the cooking started I decided to start it off right.  The beer pours out a jet black body with coffee-brown edges and nearly no head.  Just an oil-slick formation of head particles clumping together.  Tiny sparkling bubbles gather around the rim, but other than than its zippo.

The aroma has coffee notes, black strap molasses, vanilla extract and chocolate covered caramel candy.  Very tame though even with all the aromas getting flung around.  It really didnt leap out of the glass as some stouts can.

Flavor has a very smooth roasted coffee/dark chocolate combo.  Vanilla creeps into the flavor when it hits its stride, a touch of smoke, and soy sauce notes too.  Seemed slightly salty somehow too, and the roasted malt bitterness goes a long way with this beer.

The coating effect on the glass is nice, although it doesnt cling as long like some can.  Smooth and supple on the mouth.  Nothing harsh or over-bearing.  The sweetness really seems to be held in check for a sweet stout, which was welcome.  Some can really get out-of-hand with the lactose.  A nice beer to start off Christmas Eve.

Sometimes I get creamy chocolate, other sniffs yield cigarette ash.  Hmm.  Inky pour, jet black, hard to produce much of a mocha head, though there is an active carbonation struggling through the body.  Creamy lactose comes across a bit tart like fresh yogurt.  Dark roast coffee.  Never really gets creamy but there is a smooth body that seems to be rounded out with oats.  Its the twang that prevents me from loving this.
DecemBeer. Sample from a bottle shared by decaturstevo.  Dark brown to black, tan head.  Sweet, berries, roast aroma.  Taste is nice and sweet, roasty, chocolate, malty.

Very dark brown pour with a thin dark tan head that fades quickly.  Aroma is alcohol and roasted malt.  Tastes like cocoa and cream.  Full bodied with pleasant silky mouthfeel.  Finish is slightly bitter.

Bottle from a trade with StFun. Pours black with brown head. Aromas of burnt malts and chocolate. Slightly sweet roasted malt flavor with chocolate, coffee, some earthiness with a mildly ashy finish.  Full body with minimal carbonation. Thanks Josh.

Bottle, about a year or so of age on this one. Pours a solid black, some brown notes show up around the edges where the light gets through, no head to speak of. Notes of chocolate, roast malt and some vague sweet notes show up in the aroma. Flavor is more of the same, chocolate, roasted malt and a touch of vanilla in the background. Slightly acidic and slightly bitter finish.

12 oz bottle. Poured black in color with a thin brown head that left very light lacing on the glass. Aroma of milk chocolate, and light roast. Tastes of dark chocolate, lactose sweetness, light coffee, roasted malts.  Roasty finish lingers for a while and is quite nice.

i had 3 of these yesterday and wasnt crazy about them. todays is tasting a lot better. i recall liking their oatmeal stout more. this is tasting better tonight than the samuel smith oatmeal stout i just drank.

From a trade with coyotehunter.  Poured very dark brown with a brown head that was almost one-finger tall.  The aroma was roasted malt, thin coffee and light chocolate.  The flavor was on the sweet side, with artificial tasting chocolate rolling over a base of smoky, roasted malts.  Almost medium bodied mouthfeel.  A little bit better than OK.

12 oz. bottle - pours clear dark brown with thin to no head; roasted milk chocolate; sort of sweet but texture and flavor profile is very thin; sweet, dry and roasty with mild richness; easily the weakest of the 5 stouts
Pours black with a brown/tan creamy head. Smells of toasted malt, coffee, some expresso. Taste is smooth with a light coffee and bitter chocolate which lingers. Finishes nice.

Pours a deep black with a small espresso swirl head. The aroma is big and pungent with some burnt toasty and coffee. The flavor follows with a big creamy flavor with some bitter coffee and dark chocolate. Palate is big and creamy, wonderful stout.
Dark black pour with a brown head. Aroma of sweetness, roasted malt, slight hint of coffee. Taste is sweet, creamy- roasted malt, lactose sweetness. Had a dry finish. A good beer.

Bottle at home ... Big thanks to SanTa FUN (like what i did there ?) ...Nice dark solid shiney black ... thin brown head ... nice toffee roast malt ... milk suger nose ... soft milk chocolate front ... quite a lot of hop in background ... tiny coffee ... nice solid roast heading to charcoal but not quite there ... very enjoyable stout ... totally solid...
Black color with a rich tan head. Chocolately aroma, sweet, creamy, and bitter chocolate flavor. Smooth creamy mouthfeel. Smooth all the way around.  Tasty finish.

Tried this side by side with One.  To be honest, there just wasnt that much of a difference between the two of them.  Good roasted characters with hints of chocolate and coffee but no real depth to it.  I would drink it again but I wasnt in love with it.

2008 Bottle - Thanks motortoddhead! - Pours dark and thick, with a small dk brown head...aroma is coffee, cocoa and charred wood with a creamy malt backbone...flavour is similar, bitter dark chocolate, roast, the slightest green pepper...slightly sweet on the front and completely dry by the finish...very drinkable!

bottle thanks to daknole.  black with a khaki head.  nose is creamy chocolate, roasted malts and dates.  very nice on the palate with a smooth subtle roasted chocolate flavor with a smooth roasted malt finish.

Aroma pops up during the pour which is a good sign. Sweet lactose aromas with chocolate and some roasted malt. Very dark and a rich thick head.  Flavor is sweet and creamy with some dark chocolate, a bit of charcoal and burn toast. Light sourness and a little grape juice in the back ground. Palate is mild with a dryness on the duration. Good.

A Mes rate: bottle as a present to Sim from the very generous Mr. Curlow.I dont think I have ever seen such a black and viscous beer ever. Its quite amazing. Full on American chocolate accented milky stout. And a pretty bloody good. Very sweet all round but balanced really well with a faint tarty bitterness from all the chocolate. Big burnt roasty notes and some faint oaky character. Sweet again in the finish with some chalky chocolate. Really good.

12 ounce bottle shared by and with CrellMoset. Thanks! Pours pitch black and looking like oil. Thin brown head with good head retention and lacing. Aroma is roasted malts with caramel and light smoke. Sweet finish. Taste is roasted malts, tobacco, smoke. Slightly sweet finish but dry and lightly tart throughout. Medium bodied. Good beer,
Pours a thick glass staining black. Nose is roasty malt, sweet caramel and sligth smoke. Flavor is sweet sugar, burnt barley, smoke, ash and coffee. Mouthfeel is very creamy.

Bottle. Pours a dirty motor oil black with a thin dark brown head that quickly fades. Aromas of chocolate, roasted coffee and a slight hint of graham crackers. Flavors are rich, dark, burnt chocolate, relatively smooth and a slight hint of sweetness comes through with some mild carbonation. Finish is dry, burnt and bitter. Tasted directly after a Bells Double Cream Stout, very similar in taste and style, both enjoyably good brews.

On tap @ HopCat Grand Rapids.  Pours dark brown with a tan head.  Nose is roast, coffee, dark chocolate, and some bitter.  Flavor is about the same with dryness, roast, and earthy flavor.  Nice and mellow milk stout.
Bottle.  Black pour with a medium brown head.  Coffee aroma with chocolate and creamy vanilla.  Flavors of licorice, chocolate and sugar with a roasty finish.

Shared a 12 oz bottle with MereLikesBeer. Poured an opaque brown with small tan head. This beer, despite its high percentile, wasnt too far above average. The flavors were classic stout, with honestly no "wow" factor to speak of. Oh well. Cheers!

I shared a bottle of this with BeerBaron617, and we didnt like it.  It pours a very dark brown/black with a thin brown head.  It has a rather subtle aroma, very light, not too chocolaty or coffeeish..  It tastes bitter, and I dont really like it a whole lot.  Nothing all too amazing about this beer, and the mouthfeel isnt all too creamy, and its just not too good
Thanks wavers1.  Poured very black  @RBSG09 Grand Tasting, roasted malts, coffee, molasses, chocolate.

Bottle.  Pours an inky black with hardly any head.  Aroma of booze, sweet roasted malt, charred malt, and molasses.  Flavor of lots of bitter chocolate and roasted malt and roasted chocolate notes.  A touch boozy but rather tasty!
7/4/8/4/15 (3.8/5)

Bottle, thanks to tjthresh. Aroma of bitter chocolate, some charred malt. Flavor blossoms with loads of bitter chocolate and milk chocolate, very milky chocolate, but still a lot of hardcore chocolate too. Perhaps not as complex as One (which I just had), but more fun and luscious for me.

12 oz bottle courtesy of SamGamgee.  Poured a very dark brown with a minimal tan head. Nose of chocolate with a hint of a dark roasted coffee. Rich, most likey from the milk, malt and chocolate in the taste.  Very fine stout with nice finish in the mouth.

12oz bottle.   Black with a tan head.   Lots of deeply roasted coffee in the aroma with rich malty sweetness and dark chocolate.   The flavor is like sweetened coffee.   Robustly malty, but with a dry finish and strong roast.   Medium bodied with a rich texture and lower carbonation.   Drinks more like a regular stout, though it is getting up to imperial strength.   I really wish this was available around here.

Bottle courtesy SamGamgee. Pours pitch black with a tan creamy head. Aromas of cinnamon brown sugar, lactose, cocoa, coffee, dark chocolate. Flavor is a big dose of roasted malts with a finish exactly like dark chocolate. Nice bitterness. Doesnt quite live up to the wonderful aroma. Medium-heavy body, dry finish. Pretty darn good.

Pours a pitch black with highlights of brown, minimal dark tan head, no lacing.  Aroma of roasted malt, dark chocolate, and ever so slight coffee.  Flavor matches well with a bit of sweetness and creaminess to it, big surprise huh?  Goes down very easy and is quite enjoyable.
Bottle. Pours opaque blackish brown with no head. Smoky coffee aroma. Medium body and light carbonation. Lightly sweet coffee and chocolate taste and a dry finish.

Bottle 35,5 cl. Courtesy of KimJohansen. Pours completely opaque black with a light brown head. Fat aroma of hard roasted malt. Quite full-bodied, hard roasted malts - loads of it - fat vanilla accents. Some malt bitterness in the finish. 270509

courtesy of frampin.
pours black, thin mocha head with nice golden lacing.
Aroma, dark fruits, malts.
Taste, coffee, malts, some hints of lactose light bitter palate with warming alcohol that has hints of bitter chocolate with a slight smoke profile?
Black with a medium deep beige head. Sweet aroma with burned malt, dark bitter chocolate and dark overripe plums. Excellent balance and warming alcohol toward the end.

Black pour with a short lived, 1-finger, tan head.  Lots of dark chocolate aroma with hints of smoke, coffee, and some lacto sourness.  Lots of milk chocolate flavor with some more smoke, coffee, lacto sourness, brown sugar, and a hint of dark fruit.  Creamy full body with soft carbonation.

12 fl oz bottle. Pours black with a small tan head. Aroma is light fruity and roasted malt. Light smoked touch. Acidic, roasted malt, dark chocolate and a light smoked note. Acidic, fruity and roasted malt flavoured finish.

Rich black color. Inviting aroma of creamy caramel warming on the stove before gracing an apple. Malt, nuts and toffee, roasted coffee and a hint of chocolate licorice. Finishes sweet and even a little thin, something that coerces you into another pull.

Pours black with mahogany edges and a 2 finger caramel brown head that has great retention. Aroma is roast, sweet chocolate, lots of toasted hazelnut and pralines, toasted grains, some grilled fruit and mochachino. Flavor is lots of roasted barley at first, milk chocolate, lots of toasted nut notes, sweet toffee, creamy caramel, chocolate milkshake and a nice amount of roast and bitterness to finish while still maintaining its rich sweetness. Palate is medium to thick with a creamy feel and soft carbonation. Good stuff, one of the better all around sweet stouts that I have had.
Rich dark thick black with not much head. Aroma of smoke and some sugar with roasted malts. Taste is sweet and sugary and a little creamy with a nice roasty bitterness and a hint of smoke.

Pours thick and dark with a chocolate head.  This is about the perfect appearance for a stout.  Nice.  Aroma is a strong roast, like a campfire, and chocolate.  The taste is not too strong and not weak at all.  Great balance of chocolate, roast and sweetness.  The finish is sweet chocolate and lasts a while.  This is pretty damn good.

So black virtually no red was visible during the pour.  A dark brown head doesnt last long and ends as a ring.  The aroma is roasted with chocolate.  A nice thick feel.  Flavor is pleasantly complex with chocolate, coffee, dark fruit, anise, and milk.  Hops provide a nice zing that comes in waves moving from the tip of the tongue to the back.  There is also some peppery spiciness.  Finish is a bit thin and more hop based.  This is a very flavorful stout and an interesting one.
12oz bottle. Pours a dark black with almost no head. Aroma is chocalate and roasted malt with a hint of a nutty finish. Taste is similar and very creamy.

A dark black color body with a brown frothy head,that lingers a bit then fades to a nice lace leaving rim. Aroma of chocolate,dark roasted malt, and a sugary lactic note. Flavor is pretty simple, bitter and milk chocolate, roasted malt and a lactic milky quality,well balanced. Creamy,smooth mouthfeel,medium carbonatrion, and a sweet malty finish,quite drinkable and good.Dark Horse is always a treet.
bottle, dark brown with small foam, aroma is chocolate and roast, fermented fruit, chocolate and some leather, finish is smooth

UPDATED: APR 3, 2009 12 oz bottle from a One, Too, Tres, Fore mixed pack from Merchants.  Pours black with a small brown head.  I am immediately taken aback (in a good way) by the aroma: intensely sweet and creamy with caramel, vanilla, and chocolate.  Flavor is similar, with sweet vanilla and caramel accompanying a roasted coffee and cocoa backbone.  I think my sweet tooth is acting up, but damn this is a fun beer to drink.

This beer was awesome. The appearance was black as night with dark tan head, rocky on the pour.  Lots of carmel & milk chocolate with some whipped topping, toasted marshmellows and roasted nuts.  Like rocky road in a beer.  YUM
Tap, thanks sersdf.  Side by side with one.  Basically the same beer except this was more roasty and had a more astringent finish.
Poured black with a tan head. Aroma of candy. Some chocolate and caramel. Sweet throughout.
Tastes a bit like coffee, not very thick, a little hollow tasting. Pretty decent but nothing worth writing home about.

12 oz bottle from the Binny Singles Rack (Orland Park, IL) cellared for some time. The cleaning out continues, with barely a dent put in. Pours a nice dark blackish hue with brown and red around the edges. Decent brownish head that dissipates to a small amount, laces well. Largely opaque, with a possible exception being the edges. Aromas are a nice blend of chocolate, coffee, creamy sweetness, roasted malts which are a little subdued by the sweetness. Initial has a medium body, moving quickly to bittersweet chocolate, coffee, and lighter roasted malts. Some caramel, dessert-y sweetness, lactose, and roasted flavors come through fuller in the body. Still a bit light on flavor / a touch watery for the ABV. Sustained aftertaste, and a less powerful palate palate sticker. Light bitterness on the finish helps to balance, keeping this far from being cloying especially coupled with some decent roast. Not bad at all. Cheers!

Pours black. Not much head, residual at the bottom of the bottle. Aroma is roasted coffee, a little chocolate. The flavor is roasted, nuttinees, coffee, creamy, think in the mouth feel. Long lasting feel in the mouth, creamy very good.

12 oz bottle. I have liked cream/milk stouts before, liking how smooth they are, so I am excited to try this. Pours a brownish/black with a half finger high brown head. Smells of chocolate and roasted coffee, very smooth smell to it. Tastes of roasted coffee (lightly) and some chocolate, but it is very smooth and light. Weak-bodied feel, but I expected this from a cream stout. Kind of feels like drinking milk, as it coats your mouth. You can taste the milk sugar in it, giving it a sweet feel. Very nice cream stout

Bottle - Pours black with a dark tan, quickly dissipating head. Smells roasty and chocolately. Taste is way roasty with a bit of coffee, milk, and campfire tastes. Finishes bitter and a little off. Pretty silky in the mouth, but the carbonation was distracting. Overall a fine stout.

Bottle. Pours a deep black with a disappearing tan head. Nose is toasted malt.
Flavors are roasted malt, coffee bean, and hints of chocolate. Mouth is medium bodied with a mild alcohol burn. Not sure this is a sweet stout but it is a good stout!

Bottle from Archer Liquors. Pours really dark with a dark tan head that is at least two fingers. Smooth aromas of coffee, chocolate and toast. Medium body with very mild carbonation. Flavor is strongly coffee, with some chocolate, and some burnt malt. Really nice brew. Lots cheaper than Paradox, and dang near as tasty! Know that.

Bottle.  Pours a midnight black.  Looks a little like motor oil.  Small dark tan head that dissapates quickly.  Almost no lacing.  Very nice chocolate milk aroma.  Taste is chocolately and creamy, but not too sweet, maybe just right.  Smooth, not much carbonation.  Very relaxing brew perfect for a winter evening.  Really enjoy just about everything that comes out of the Dark Horse.
Pours pitch black. Light cocoa aroma. Roast malt and sweet chocolate flavor, but also noticeable hop bitterness for balance. Creamy mouthfeel as one would expect. Decent stout.
Bottle. Pours black with a decent cocoa colored head. Slight roasted bitterness, hints of sweetness.

Thanks 17thfloor for this one! Pours very nearly black with a creamy lingering light brown head. Very rich aroma of sweet chocolate and roasted malt with a nice molasses and vanilla. Flavor starts with a creamy roasted and burnt chocolate malt, light coffee, a hint of smokiness, and a bit of dark fruit. A somewhat milky quality though not quite as complex or rich as other sweet stouts. Finishes slightly bitter with some hop presence and less malty. Also a hint of alcohol lingers. Medium body and low to moderate carbonation. Pretty decent and easy drinking sweet stout.

Bottle courtesy of Guerde  thanks Andy!  Pours a pitch black with a half finger brown head that leaves minor lacing.  No light getting through this stuff.  The nose is roasty malt, light smoke, milk chocolate and coffee grounds.  Taste is milk chocolate, burnt malt, ashy cocoa and some mild dark fruits with a bitter coffee/hop finish.  Medium, semi-creamy mouth feel.  The more beers I try from this brewery the more I like it.  Another good one.  Thanks Andy!

UPDATED: APR 11, 2010 [1.17.09] Pours a very dark near black brown wit ha slight reddish tint and a minimal fizzy brown head.  Lovely aroma, hard roasted malts, lots of chocolate, lesser so coffee, touch of hops.  Flavor is coffee and cream with sugar, touch of hops and a bit grainy, not as creamy as most cream stouts,  probably my least favorite of the series;  It is definitely the most straightforward.  Medium body a bit watery and thin with sparse fizzy carbonation, not really creamy, more sugary.  8.4.7.3.14 . . . . . [same bottle aged about a year 4.11.10] aged well, quite nice now, roasty, smooth, creamy, full of flavor, no real off oxidation flavors 8.4.8.4.15

Pours a deep dark brown.  The nose was a strong coffee malt with some chocolate, & vanilla undertones. It comes across the palate as creamy with the taste of chocolate and then a strong coffee to follow.
this big stout does is sweet and smooth without many of the problems associated with big beers.   nice rich aroma and clean sweet malty roasty smooth flavor.

12oz bottle courtesy of MatSciGuy - thanks! Pours black - pitch black. Dark greyish tan head. Aroma is malt, coffee, hot chocolate, and molasses. Flavor is lighter than expected, and lighter than DH Stout One. Sweet, milky and smoky.

UPDATED: JAN 1, 2014 TAP: at the Happy Gnome (St. Paul, MN) on 1.17.09. Dark, somewhat creamy, roasty, and dark chocolate smell but muted. Initial flavor is muted, but then the chocolate flavor comes on, followed by coffee.

(bottle) Pours black with a thin dark tan head.  Aroma is very complex right from the start, with scents of smoke, coffee, vanilla, beef jerky, cherry skin, light soy, and considerable roasted malt that really comes together to form a pleasant scent.  The great complexity displayed by the aroma does not quite carry over into the taste, but its still nice enough.  Theres a unique competition between the low-key sweetness of the milk sugar, and the strong roasted/smoky characters of the malt.  The roasted character wins out in the end and produces a green snap pea pod flavor towards the finish with a hint of graham cracker showing up later on.  Another well brewed stout from Dark Horse.

On tap at the Bavarian Lodge, Lisle, Il. Shaker served. Black/brown with a foamy, dark tan head, and thick, clingy lace. Aroma of dark, roasted coffee, a touch of sweetness, smoke, and wood. Flavor has a more intense note of smoke and char, with coffee and dark cocoa following. Would have liked a little more bitterness in the finish.

This one pours about as dark as a beer can get. Black. The aroma has some roasted coffee and a hint of chocolate. At first the roasted malt is about all I taste but I start to pick up more and more sweetness from the milk sugar as this one warms. Mouthfeel is creamy. Not very carbonated at this point.

UPDATED: JAN 8, 2009 12 ounce bottle. Poured a jet black color with a very small tan head that disappeared quickly. It also had almost no carbonation. The initial aroma was very nice with a lot of bitter chocolate, roasted malts, and coffee. It reminded me of an oatmeal stout. However as this beer sat it lost a lot of its aromas. After a while it only smelled like faint roasted malts. The taste consisted of a lot of bitter chocolate and coffee with roasted malts in the background. Finished a bit bitter. It had a medium bodied mouthfeel and felt creamy. I would have rated this a lot higher if it hadnt lost some of the aromas and tastes as it sat. It was a good beer though.

Nearly black pour with a light brown head.  Nice roasty aromas, small amount of milk chocolate.  Full bodied smooth mouthfeel, nearly creamy.  Heavy roasted malt and coffee but balanced with a bit of chocolate milk. Finishes with just a hint of bitterness.  I thought this was excellent, but I seem to like many brews I’ve had of this style.  This like the other top of the style really balance out the sweetness, which makes them have a nice amount of complexity.
user_location: from Michigan now in Charlotte, North Carolina, USA

text: 12 oz bottle. Black with a very small tan head. Aroma of coffee, chocolate, and lots of roasted malts. Flavor, chocolate, some coffee, some bittersweet notes, extra roasty malts and a smooth creamy mouthfeel.  Decent stout that did little for me.

Dark black pour. Another great beer in their awesome series of stouts. Dark black pour with a thin brown head. Roasty, chocolatey, coffee pour. The lactose makes it a bitter lighter and adds some sourness. Great mouthfeel. Excellent Milk stout.

Bottle.  These guys know how to make a good dark beer.  This one pours opaque brown/black with a thin tan head, it laces the glass nicely.  Aroma has coffee roast, strong chocolately malts and a creamy milky character.  Malts are sweet, creamy with a strong coffee roast finish.  Full bodied.

12 oz. bottle.  Pours that stouty brown-black that we all know and love. Less head than a loveless marriage. Aroma has cocoa, slightly soured milk, and (like all DH stouts) tons of roast.  Flavor is initially sweet but finishes with coffee bitterness and a touch of sourness.  Creamy mouthfeel and overall incredibly drinkable.
Lovely aromas with lots of milk and cream and lactose. Thick body and sweet. An excellent stout that I have not had in a long time.

[Bottle] Pours a nearly deep brown with an extremely dark tan head. Aroma is lactose, roasted barley, and some bakers chocolate. Very rich initial mouthfeel. The nice sweetness from the lactose right at the front is balanced by a roasted, slightly bitter finish. A this beer appears deceptively simple, but it is a well done and perfectly balanced brew.

12oz bottle. Pours black with rich dark tan head. Aroma is rich with roasted malt and chocolate, also picking up notes of vanilla and caramel. Flavor is roasted malt, burnt coffee, chocolate, brown sugar, vanilla and caramel. Nice mouthfeel but finishes bitter due to coffee. Could use more chocolate and less coffee in my opinion as I like my sweet stouts a little softer on the palate. Still this is a fine stout.

Pours black with a brown head. Nice lacing that never fully dissipates. Aroma is of toasted malt, vanilla, coffee, caramel, brown sugar. Taste starts with a harsh coffee bite, with vanilla notes. Nice toasty malt backbone with some nice caramel, brown sugar, and smoke. Light, yet sticky mouthfeel. Lingering vanilla taste. Decent, but not above averge.

UPDATED: FEB 3, 2012 On tap at Jerrys. Black with big, foamy, cappuccino head / Complex, smooth nose of tobacco, coffee, chocolate, and cedar box / Medium body, chewy and dry, but a touch watery, with good balance and finish / Flavors of cigar box, dark roast coffee, bittersweet chocolate, vanilla, caramel, oak, and bourbon / This 2011 bottle suffers from a weak body as compared to my notes on the 2008..

12 oz. bottle.  Black color without any head.  Sweet aroma with hints of chocolate and hops.  Nice creamy mouthfeel.  Flavor is really nice.  Again, chocolate notes and some roasted malt.  Finish is slightly bitter.  Tasty beer.

Pours deep brown and heavy with an almost nonexistent, chunky head.  Nice aroma of hops and bittersweet chocolate.  Flavors of chocolate & vanilla with a nice hoppy presence which helps balance the beer.    Long, bittersweet chocolate finish.
Aroma is a little weak. flavor is that of vanilla and bitter chocolate with a very smooth mouthfeel. Kind of reminds me aof a liuid Hersheys Special Dark.
Number 2 shared with Gabe. Poured black in color thin head. Nice aroma of roasted malts and chocolate. Taste was roasted malt and vanilla. An ok stout.

Bottle froms stfun, thanks josh. Black in color, not much head.  Aroma was sugary sweet. Taste was a sweet vanilla, chocolate, and roasted malt with a creamy texture. My least favorite out of the one through five series. Still a decent beer overall. Thanks josh

12 oz. bottle courtesy of a trade with yem25.  Pours black with a thin brown head that disappeared after the first sip and left no lace at all.  Pleasant aroma of roasted malt and chocolate.  The flavor is roasted malt with tobacco, chocolate and a hint of vanilla.  Very mild sweetness overall.  Not as creamy or smooth as I was expecting.  Medium-full bodied.  Decent, but falls a bit short in a few areas.

I had never had a cream stout before.  I think it is something I will dwell into in the near future.  Sweet taste, ;ast impression on the tongue, not bitter in the least to me, nice chocolate malt flavor.  Very good!  Thanks Optigon!

12oz bottle.  Wow!  One of the best sweet stouts I’ve tried in a LONG time.  Pours midnight black with a thin dark chocolate head.  Tons of cocoa, toffee and plum on the nose.  Flavor was much of the same with a very smooth and sweet finish.
Pitch black with a brown head. Nice roasted malt and tobacco juice aroma. Creamy, full bodied mouthfeel. Very good flavor of rich, roasted malts with sweet earthy tobacco leaf. Great stout here.
user_location: Same Trailer, Different Park, Louisiana, USA

text: Pours pitch black with a short-lived mocha head that recedes to a ring leaving very little lacing.  Aroma is mostly roasted malts with a hint of lactose in the form of bakers chocolate.  The taste has a coffee bitterness up front before giving way to a substantial burnt malt backbone.  The finish brings back the bitterness, but in a pretty unpleasant chalky way.  The mouthfeel is a tad watery with very little carbonation.  This is a pretty average stout and not as enjoyable as the first in the series for me.  Im hoping for more with the rest of the series.

Bottle, hurricane glass.  Aroma of roast barley and berries.  Pours dark brown, black in the glass, with a brief-lived coffee-brown head.  No lacing to speak of.  Starts off with dark fruits, cranberries and cola, before turning to a sweet creaminess, that, if not nearly as viscous, evokes draining the liquid from a bowl of peaches and cream.  Vanilla and dark chocolate, with hints of bright coffee in the finish.  Drinks very smooth, with some prickles of carbonation.

12 oz. bottle from B&B (Grand Rapids, MI) served in pint glass- poured blacker than motor oil that hasn’t been changed in a year, low carbonation, dark brownish tan head 5mm thick formed but went away a little too quickly.  Aroma of coffee, roasted malt, and heavy cream.  Hits the mouth with a wide body, malt is very tasty, bit of cream in the middle with bakers chocolate in the background, finish slowly fades like a late summer sunset on the pier in Ludington.  Yeah, DH rocks, tell me something that I didn’t learn a LONG time ago...

Very black, brown small head, fair lace. Very sweet, loads of coffee, roasted, light bitter. Medium body, bit dusty. Very flavorful, very drinkable, not exceptional but good.

Scored this in my Secret Santa package.  Thanks Saint Nick!  12oz bottle pours an oily, opaque black with a thin, slgihtly beige head that settled into a faint ring around the glass.  Aroma of roasted malts, toast, licorice, molasses, coffee, brown sugar and slight chocolate.  Flavor are similar, toasted, roasted malts at the forefront with only slight coffee (with a cream dimension), licorice and mexican chocolate.  Heavy on the palate and creamy.

Bottle.  Pours very dark with little head or lacing.  Aroma of coffee, chocolate, malt.  Taste is also of coffee, chocolate, roasted malt.  Finish is chocolate and lightly bitter.  Mouth is smooth, full, creamy.

Thanks to Rogueone for sharing a bottle, part of a Too-Tres-Fore-Plead The Fifth horizontal tasting. This brew is pitch black color with a medium thin tan head that diminishes quickly. Rings of lacing on the glass. Bold roasted coffee aroma, along with some dark cocoa and malt. Rich and smooth body with roasty and smoky characteristics. Coffee, malt and chocolatey flavors throughout. The finish is cocoa with a nutty chocolate aftertaste. Solid all around.

UPDATED: AUG 30, 2009 too date this is the best sweet stout i have drank. been sitting on this one for awhile. aromas of coffee and roasted mallts,poured black with very little to no head taste are of coffee,chocolate and roasted grains, mouth is oily and smooth with a slight bitterness my overall impression is this beer rocks the next up from this great american brewer of fine stouts ie tres blueberry stout a dry stout cant wat to try all of thier 5 stouts

Brown with a very thin brown head.  Aroma of roasted malts, smoke, chocolate, coffee, sweet malt, molasses, alcohol and cocoa.  Taste of sweet malt, coffee, roasted malt, coffee and alcohol.  Creamy and bit thin with a finish that’s mildly bitter with some sweetness to it.  Preferred the one and three stout versions to this.
Pours exactly like motor oil from the bottle with a thick dark borwn head of foam.  Mild cocoa aroma.  Creamy and malty as advertised.  Very balanced and enjoyable.

Bottle. Pours like their other three big stouts, black as night, medium viscosity, and with a deep, dark burgundy/brown head. The aroma is very roasty with hints of a tangy darker fruit. Cocoa notes are quite prevalent along with the also noticeable coffee. Smooth lactose notes are very, very subtle. The brew is somewhat light on the tongue but provides some nice smooth creaminess. The initial flavour is very milky with hints of a light pomegranate tanginess. As the brew proceeds to pass the tongue, tanginess bursts a little before a nice blast of chocolate mixes perfectly with the milky qualities. Piquant notes of roastines really enhances the cocoa flavours and creates a dryness that counterbalances the creamy lactose. Mmmm, delicious.

Courtesy of CigarCityBrew. Pours deep darkness with almost no head. The aroma is bold and inviting. I get highly roasted to burnt malts along with chocolate, coffee and sweet molasses. Smells great. The flavor enters with some smoothness and starts with a black licorice note then vanilla and burnt malts. It then moves into coffee, chocolate and more burnt malts. Everything goes together nicely.

The Dan Journal #199.  Tasted 7/10/08.  12oz bottle.  Dark brwon hue.  Gnarly eyeball of khaki head.  More toffee and cream in the aroma than the One Stout.  Subtle dose of alcohol in the nose.  More so vanilla and creamy and richer.  Mild bitterness.  These Guys are good!

Poured dark brown with ruby highlights and a large fizzy/frothy brown head.  Rich sweet aroma of chocolate, dark fruit, a bit of alcohol, some light bitter coffee.  Flavor follows with notes of roasted coffee beans, some 60% cacao bitter chocolate, a bit of vinous fruits, some dry alcohol.  Im impressed how this beer balances sweetness and bitter roastiness.  At first I thought they traded off, with sweetness coming first and bitterness following, but as I went though the glass I felt more that they somehow worked side-by-side, the virtual ideal for a milk stout.  Mouth feel is sufficiently creamy for the style.  Overall I was very impressed by beer which finally penetrated my select group of favorite stouts that are not brewed Bells.

Bottle courtesy of someone from the Tampa crew. Pours black with a small tan head that leaves good lacing. Aroma of coffee, chocolate, and sweet malt. Taste is the same as aroma. Medium creamy mouthfeel with a mild amount of bitterness and well hidden alcohol. Very good.

Bottle.  Pours a dark brown black body with a creamy white head. Aroma is sweet and matly and some chocolate malt.  Flavor is milk chocolate, chocolate malt, lactose mostly.  Easy to drink.  Good beer.

Bottle, courtesy CIgarCityBrew I believe. Black pour, not much of a head, and a ring of white lacing on the glass. Chocolate nose, giant roasted malts, some oats. Creamy chocolate flavors, some lactose, oats, malts are very fulfilling, with full of life. So good. Smooth and frothy mouthfeel, drinkable, delicious.

thick black with a (dark tan rich head) pour....roasted malts and sweets and chocolate aroma....bitter chocolate and strong coffee flavor and a very good thick mouth feel......Dark Horse has yet to let me down.

Bottle at Noogfest Four-O.  Pours red-black with small beige head. Aroma is roasty, a touch sweeter than One. Flavor is the same roasty sweetness with some slight caramel character. Good, but a little less interesting than its predecessor.
This one is harsher than the One. Its less creamy in body as well. Nice beer though.

5-19-08 bottle shared with lb4lb thanks to The_Epeeist and demitriustown 
Brown black pour with a thin tan head that fades almost immediately.  Smell is light and mild raosted malt.  Flavor is lightly sweet and nutty.  Thin mouthfeel - with a slightly low carbonation.  It has some raosted elements but overall is just a bit bland.

Bottle at Noogfest 08. Pours midnight black with a brown head. Dominate coffee in the nose, but pleasant. Medium to full bodied with some dryness on the palate, slightly creamy texture. Flavor of dark bakers chocolate and coffee with a moderate balancing bitterness. This is good but lacks the wow factor that I find in other Dark Horse stouts.

Bottle. Pours inky black with almost no head. The aroma has definite hints at coffee, some chocolate, and a bit of sweet wooden character. The mouthfeel is pretty decent, nice and slick. Hints of vanilla, almonds, sharp coffee, thin chocolate, and a roasty finish. The whole thing seems a bit thinner than I would expect from Dark Horse. Ive been completely blown away by their stouts and porters, but this one is just good.

Bottles from The_Epeeist and demitriustown.  Thanks!  Pours dark black with a tan head.  Roasty malt and cream smell with a similar taste along with a faint smokiness too.  Medium to light carbonation and a nice lightly rich body.  Solid cream stout.

Very dark pour....small amount of brown foam. Roasted malt on the nose...hints of strong coffee and bitter chocolate. Big flavor of roasted chocolate malts, coffee and bitter chcolate. Mouthfeel is definitly creamy....interesting use of milk sugar. Smooth, bitter finish. Not as sweet as other cream-type stout.....the bitter roastedness is more similar to a porter...but still good overall.

UPDATED: MAY 19, 2008 Bottle from discount liquor. Dark brown with that same red brown head. Slight coffee with chocolate, dried out aroma. Nice sweet chocolate with a little condensed milk flavor.  Medium, creamy body.  Very nice.

Bottle courtesy of tetrik -- thanks! This is my first of the series, and if the others are this good Im in for a real treat as I work my way through them.

Pours a ridiculous inky black with a gorgeous deep brown head. Lovely roasty nose, splendid gently sweet (Thai iced coffee) flavor, chocolate , plenty of roast in the finish, just a tiny bit smoky,  and enough hops to make their mark melting with the coffee close. Ah, this is a fine, fine stout. Bravo!

Pours an incredibly dark brown to black with  healthy enough, dense enough, small bubbled tan head.  The nose is full of chocolate and roast over a creamy smoothness.  Big burly malt.  Bittersweet chocolate.  Full creamy softly carbonated body, thick with stuff!  Lovely.  The flavors are in line with the nose.  Thick sweet palpable chocolatey malt.  Some floral hops, mostly sweet creamy acidic chocolate with some fruit coffee roast sort of flavors towards the end.  Long lingering roast and acidity.  This is a really delightful beer, Ive forgotten how well crafted it is.

Pours a nice deep black with a thin dark tan head. The aroma is mostly of dark, roasted malts with some hints of cream/oatmeal. The flavor hits first with a big, dark roasty character, which then fades away into a simple but very pleasant coffee/dark chocolate finish. Very nice creamy mouthfeel. Very nice stout overall.
Black viscous pour with brown head and spotty lacing.   Malty aroma.  Big  roasted malt flavor quickly yielding to a nice chocolate & coffee flavor.  Well Balanced and easy to drink

12 oz. bottle from Dark Horse.  Pours darkest black; no light is getting through this baby.  Carmel head dissipates quickly, releasing a rich malty bouquet of chocolate and espresso.  Smooth and creamy, leaving milk sugar on the tongue. Mmmmmm.
user_location: I F&ckin hate those guys from, Ohio, USA

text: Courtesy Stine.  Pours midnight black, like oil, with a tiny little bubbly brown head,  Smells of rich, roasty dark malts, some smooth chocolate, with maybe a touch of some dark fruit as well.  The flavor is mildly carbonated, with a good dose of that chocolate and toasted malts.  Fairly sweet, but not as sweet as I was expecting.  Nice, thick mouthfeel, with a lightly bitter finish.  Pretty nice, but I like the One better.

Bottle courtesy of bdigi66.  Pours dark brown with no discernible head.  Smells of caramel and molasses.  Tastes tarte, creamy, and sweet with a slightly bitter finish.  This one has lots of malt depth to it.  Very nice!
Bottle: Pours very dark with small brown head.  Aroma of malts, coffee and a sweet smell that I could not identify.  Very drinkable.

12 oz bottle.  Dark, thin liquid.  No real aroma.  No head, very little carbonation.  Flavor is roasted malts and coffee.   Yada yada yada, you know the drill.....all of these sweet stouts taste the same.   This was ok.  Kind of a let down after having the "one" a few minutes ago.

Pours black with a small disappearing tan head.   The aroma is just what I expect from a stout with lactose.  Just roasted malts with this odd sweetness I associate with the lactose.  Flavor is chocolate and roasted malts without much complexity.  It finishes with a nice bitter bubbly feel.  All right beer.

Bottle, thanks Acknud!! Wow this is an intense stout.  Poured no head at all.  Thick and almost black.  Actually coated the glass and left it with a brown tint.  Big time coffee and chocolate flavors and aromas.  Great balance and rich mouthfeel.  This is a great stout!

Pours out black with a small brown head. Aroma is of some chocolate and slight roasted malt. Taste is complex and silky smooth. Light roasted malt, chocolate and a nice creamy backbone. Very drinkable and solid.

Very dark pour....small amount of brown foam. Roasted malt on the nose...hints of strong coffee and bitter chocolate. Big flavor of roasted chocolate malts, coffee and bitter chcolate. Mouthfeel is definitly creamy....interesting use of milk sugar. Smooth, bitter finish. Not as sweet as other cream-type stout.....the bitter roastedness is more similar to a porter...but still good overall.

Like the other Dark Horse stouts, this one pours absolutely pitch black and opaque.  A small ring of brown foam gathers at the rim, producing sudsy, sugary legs that slowly drip back down into the body.  The nose is as advertised, with big, roasty notes of bakers chocolate and espresso.  Sweetness comes through in the form of lactic sugars, providing nice contrast to the staunch roast.  Flavors mimic this pattern exactly, with creamy lactose showing atop bitter chocolate, roasted coffee, and scorched caramel.  Substantial and creamy in the mouth, this one goes down silky smooth, leaving lingering espresso on the rear of the tongue.  Im not a big sweet stout guy, but this one is impressive.  Definitely near the top of the genre.

This is really much better once its pretty close to room temp. Aroma is all dark malts, and a little sweet. Taste has a lot of chocolate and a lot of coffee, nice roasted malts, but also some sourness which is disagreeable. Finishes like a dream though-all of above minus the sourness. The lactose doesnt really show up all that much. Mouthfeel is too thin.
Sweet, slightly sour scent.  Notes of milk, chocolate, coffee, burnt sugar, and dishwater.  Not entirely agreeable.  Taste is off, as is the mouthfeel.

Bottle:  Dark, silky black pour...very enticing.  Notes of marshmallow cream, chocolate, brown sugar and a lingering smokiness to the roasted malt base.  Medium-full bodied mouth feel...still retains some of that creaminess.  Initially dry yet the silky chocolate aspects come through on the delivery and bring the subtle smoke and sweet fruitiness with it.  Very solid.
Pours flat and dark black.  Aroma is chocolate, cream, and lactose.  Taste is about the same.......sweet chocolate, milk, sugar.  Pretty good.

Poured flat.  Might be a bad bottle, well see.  Im going to have to re-rate after my cold is gone anyway.

Almost as good as its big brother Black Bier.  Just enough sweetness from the lactose to keep it from being too rich and dark.  Nice.

12oz bottle.  Aroma of chocolate, berries, cream, and coffee.  Black as hell with very small dark brown head that fully diminished and left no lace.  Flavor is sweet then bitter  with chocolate, roasted coffee, pipe tobacco and molasses.  Palate is full bodied and oily flat.  This is a big beer with lots of good flavors.   Really good but the lactose is going to kill me.

Black with thin dirty brown head.  Strong coffee and chocolate aroma.  Flavor is bitter coffee,  milk chocolate,  roasty malt,  smoke,  hazelnut.  Finishes slightly bitter,  creamy.  Nice carbonation.

Aroma is dark milk chocolate, and this strange bock-like blending of dark cocoa and this ineffable goodness that I can only describe as port- but less winey.
Flavor is dark chocolate, port, bitter cocoa.  
This is very straightforward, but damn good.

Bottle from Stine - thanks!  Nice looking blackish pour with a smaller head.  Aroma has a bold creamy, roastiness that mixes well with the dark chocolate and light coffee essence coming off this one.  Flavor is chocolatey-creamy with some light smokiness, a hint of espresso, and light hop bitterness.  Nice mouthfeel - Good stout with a taste doesnt quite live up to the wonderful aroma (or its close relative Black Bier), but still a nice stout from Dark Horse.
Low carbonation.  Lots of cocoa in the aroma. Tastes a bit like melted milk chocolate.  Distinct lactic finish. Very nice.

Wow! Extremely dark pour is essentially pitch black. Small cocoa head. Aroma is overpowering chocolate with a hint of dark roast. Creamy medium full body with restrained carbonation. Taste is mostly chocolate but there is a soothing lactic note and some bitter dark roast. Very nicely done. Thanks to acknud for the bottle.

Thanks to Eben for this one.  Black bodied with a small brown head.  Somewhat powdery aroma of chocolate and coffee.  Flavor is quite chocolaty as well with a gentle roastiness blended in with the flowing smooth texture.
Bottled. Almost black coloured with a small brown head. Quite roasted and sweet with notes of malt, chocolate, coffe and cream.

Bottle thanks to mreusch.  Poured a deep black color with a moderate tan head that diminished quickly.  Aroma of light roast and a earthy green character.  Light chocolate and roasted malt that leads into a earthy, almost cardboard taste, but not necessarily in a bad way.  Very creamy and smooth, easy-drinking with no real signs of alcohol.  Pretty nice beer, may be better fresh.  Thanks Matt.

12 oz. bottle via trade with pantanap - Pours a dark brown color with a thin, 1/4 finger thick tan head that faded quickly.  Very light lacing after a few good swirls.  Aroma is a very light roasted malt.  What a disappointment.  Flavor is light roasted malt and bitter sweet chocolate.  Palate is soft but dry.  Medium body.  Has a lingering dry roasted malt aftertaste.  A decent beer.  Thanks Kan.

This one received via trade with SQNfan...THANK YOU!!!  Black as coal brew with less than foam; a single swirl of caramel bubbles tried to break the surface but their attempt was futile!!!  Aroma was smores-like, with dark bitter chocolate, cedar-laden smoke, and creamy marshmallow froth.  It coated the tongue well...just missing a little somethin somethin to push it over the top.

2/25/2007:  Dark Horse Too Cream Stout pours an opaque, near black color without any sort of head or crown.  The aroma is sweet and roasty with hints of smoke and alcohol.  It reminds me a little bit of Scotch or something.  The flavor is also quite roasty with some chocolate/cocoa and that tell-tale lactose sweet, yet sour quality.  The flavor is a bit like chocolate milk made with skim milk.  There is plenty of roasted malt/char (not burnt though) flavor as well.  The body is medium-light to medium with an oily and slick mouthfeel.  I preferred the <a href=http://www.ratebeer.com/beer/dark-horse-one-o Horse One Oatmeal Stout over this one.  However, the Too Cream Stout is still quite tasty!
12 fl. oz. bottle.  Rating #204 for this beer...

Pours and oily with absolutely no head. Roasted grain, chocolate malt, and chocolate milk aroma. Taste is smooth lots of roasted grain, chocolate malt and a nice bit of hops. Finishes clean with a little bit of chocolate and hops. Very nice.

Pours a dark black with a nice tan head.  Smells of roasted malts waft from the glass.  Has a dark roasted malt flavor.  Does not have the typical cream mouthfeel Im accustomed to when drinking a cream stout.  Overall is a solid beer.
Black pour with a tan head.  Aroma is roasted malt with taste of a well hidden chocolate.  Some coffee notes.

UPDATED: FEB 6, 2008 This is the highest rated of the new DH releases, but I rank it third. The aroma is just average, and theres not much too special about the appearance. The flavor is good, nice and smooth, but lacks the "creaminess" that Id expect from a  stout called a "Cream" Stout. The taste just kind of felt average and maybe slightly bland (only when compared to other beers of its kind) Left Hands Milk Stout is a much better example of how to make a creamy stout. This one is good, lets not kid ourselves (Im being way to hard on it, because it really is tasty as hell) , but Id go with One or Tres myself.

At S/choc pre release tasting. Thin looking brown pour with tan head. Very pleasant roasted malt chocolate aroma. Flavor is a bit on the sweet side with good chocolate that tries to fade to coffee but goes a bit sour instead. Thin palate but carbonation is good. Solid just a hint on the thin side but a very nice offering.

Pours extremely dark with almost no head or carbonation. Malty almost sweet scent with hints of chocolate and kind of a roasted scent. Good malt flavor with a very smooth feel which lingers in a chocolate flavor.

Pours very dark with no head and no carbonation.  The alcohol is well hidden which is good.  The other flavors come out in the mouthfeel.  This beer coats your palate and hints of smokiness come out in the aftertaste.  Swirling this beer creates no lacing, this beer is straight blackness.  This is my favorite beer so far.
Bottle at home - club tasting. Black - brown head. Licorice, chokolate, sweetness, soft body, light smoke, burned, peppermint, roasted. Very smooth.

This was black in color and poured practically no head at all and what did emerge quickly faded away.  Scents of smoke, coffee, milk chocolate and sweet caramel.  The palate was quite smooth fading to a dry/bitter hop-driven finish.  It starts off big but fades as the finish doesnt quite deliver.

No head at all from a vigorous pour.  No carbonation.  Sweet and rich aroma.  Milk chocolate, prunes, dark roasted grains and lots of sweet caramel.  Quite the enticing aroma.  Thick, syrupy and black body.  Big coffee flavor.  Very strong.  Quite unexpected since it was not noted in the aroma.  Lots of roasted grains, bitter dark chocolate and a bit of smoked venison.  Palate is a little thinner than expected.  Alcohol is hidden very well.  Finishes roasty and dry.  A pretty good stout but a little bit lifeless.

12 oz bottle, trade extra from Stine.  This pours completely black in color with a small brown head.  Aroma is nice and roasty, with chocolate, caramel and earth.  Taste is also roasty, with dry chocolate, caramel.  Body is medium to full with caramel and light lactose sweetness.  Hints of chalk, earth, and yeast. Finishes with roasty and a light hop bitterness.  Dark Horse did a good job with these stouts, only minor complaint was that they could have been just a bit more carbonated.  Thanks again Eben.

Inky black pour with no transparency retains only a thread of brown foam around the rim.  Aroma is all thick, rustic roasted malt; firm and beefy like meat fresh from the coals.  Wisps of wild rice, tart red apple, chocolate hazelnuts, and cinnamon gather up in the bonfire smoke.  Flavor brings it a little weakly with a hollow tone, but warms up quickly into a varied but predictable set of tastes.  These are fairly needly and woodsy, like black licorice, brown sugar, molasses and holly leaves lingering in the wet soil.  Lactic flavors are very quiet, which if not exercised toward something purposefully soured tend to work counterintuitively in a rich, roasty stout, so this is a pleasant quality.  With warmth, oatmeal cookie dough, caramel, and toffee provide a soft touch of sweetness to balance the bitter, vegetal coffee and earth tones of roasted malt.  Slight citrus hop and red berry interludes here and there.  Medium to full palate is creamy and soft, with a lot of lively fruit and winey dimensions.  Very dry, cocoa, tobacco and dark roast finish.  Solid.

Pours black with an off-white head. Quite sweet. Some burnt and roasted malt aromas. Also aromas of dates. Medium to full bodied with a creamy mouthfeel. Soft carboantion. Dry, toasted finish with some sweetness.

12oz. bottle from my 07 Secret Santa: Pours a small light brown head with fair retention and lacing too boot. Black colored brew. Nose has notes of light blue berry, roast, chocolate and is a bit earthy as well. Body is medium, lightly oily on the palate, slick, coating and a tad chalky. Nice malty sweetness balanced out with roasty, bittersweet chocolate flavors, some charred notes, light fruitiness, cocoa and malted milk. Dry, roasty finish with a hint of coffee. Nice brew. Thanks Jeremy!

12oz Bottle. Heavy roast and butter cream aroma. Pretty straightforward. Pours black and rim of coffee and cream. Flavor is a bold roast, quite black and edging espresso. Not too sweet, but the milky qualities are noticeable. Rich and full. Some palatable ash. Fermented well. A well done, heavily roasted stout with minimal hop presence, as expected.

Really a fantastic beer. Super strong creamy notes in the nose, on the tongue, and on the palate. Strong roasted malts and coffee/chocolate notes. Mouthfeel is simply perfect. Creamy and full. This is what most cream stouts dream of being.

12oz. bottle, with thanks to Gregis for hauling this back from Indy for me!  Pours a dark black with a frothy dark brown head that dissipates to a large bubbly covering, moderate lacing.  Aroma is roasty and sweet, with coffee grounds, milk chocolate and a touch of molasses.  Flavor is milk chocolate, roast and slightly smoky, with that telltale milk stout lactose aftertaste.  Not a big fan of milk stouts as it is, but the lactose was a bit much on this one.
Oily as I suppose it should be. Roasted, but not too much. I didnt get much coffee notes, but some coa-coa puffs. This is a little rough going down the hatch. Decent looking with a thin head.

12oz. bottle.  Nose is full of creamy chocolate, the malts dark, roasty, toffeeish and sweet, some espresso notes and very faint smoke.  Opaque black color with a tan ring of a head.  Flavor is roasty, semi-sweet, full of chocolate and toffee, some coffeeish roast and lacto sweetness peeking through, the finish sweet with lingering dark roastiness.  Smooth and thick on the palate, body is medium-full.  Tasty.  Reminiscent of Bells Double Cream Stout.  Thanks Chris!

Bottle.  Creamy chocolate espresso aroma.  Thick black color with minimal head.  Light creamy burnt coffee flavor with moderate astringency/bitterness.  A light body than the appearance would have led me to expect.  A bit weak and on the rough side.

Courtesy of Secret Santa 07. Opaque black pour with little to no head. Aroma of coffee/roastiness. Tastes almost like a milk stout, chocolate/milky and almost peanut-butter taste. Very impressed with this brew, never had a Dark Horse beer before. Thanks Santa!

Draft courtesy of Enzofans kegerator.  Dark black/brown pour with thick tan foamy head.  Coffee and roasted malt on the nose.  Nice balance.  Bitter chocolate, coffee, and caramel.  Full creamy mouthfeel.  Slight bitter finish.  Very good.

bottle....pours a very dark brown almost black with a thin film of tan head. decent lacing on the side as well....scents of chocolate and roast....flavors of coffee grounds and roast.  some chocolate and bitter roasted finish. creamy mouth yet light mouthfeel.

12 oz. bottle, no bottling/freshness date, but I know this is the new label 2007 release, sampled in a pint glass. The ABV is 8%.

Poured as black as motor oil with a tight, compact brown head that slowly settled into a thin sudsy lacing. A light amount of splotchy lace at the top of the glass.

Lush smelling nose of heavily roasted dark malts and milk sugar. The smells really mesh together well, roasted dark coffee, lightly burnt chocolate and sweet milky lactose, quite appealing.

There is enough of an low temperature warmth to make its 8% ABV noticeable on the tongue and in back of the mouth. Smooth moderate feeling body with an airy creaminess, this is one easy sipper, quite pleasant on a cold mid-December night. The milk sugar lactose flavor does a lot to sweeten the roasted, almost burnt, dark malts, easing their nature malty bitterness. Dark roast coffee and bittersweet dark chocolate buoyed by the sugary milk flavor make this cream stout unique and highly enjoyable. In the aftertaste some coffee nuttiness lingers a bit in the palate.

An excellent holiday stout from Dark Horse, recommended if you like dark roasted tasting malty stouts.

12 oz. bottle shared by csbosox at the 12/7 tasting at Indras.  Pour is black, with a quickly disappearing tan head.  Aroma of creamy, roasty coffee notes, and some sourness.  Taste is a nice creamy mouth feel with some roasty coffee around the edges.  Good flavor start to finish.
12 oz bottle. Roast, chocoloate, lactose, and a touch of licorice. Black colored with a light khaki head. Taste is chocolate, roast, lactose, black licorice and some light spice. Night mouthfeel.

Pours a beautiful ebony with a small but frothy brown head.  Chocolate, roasted malts, coffee, Breyers vanilla.  Nice creamy texture and fairly full-bodied.  A little of the Whoppers malt balls in the flavor but not as sweet.  Quite quaffable.

Pours jet black with a small, creamy, brown head that diminishes to a thin ring of bubbles clinging to the edge of the glass. After a couple minutes it looks like a pint glass full of soy sauce. The nose is a subdued blend of dark roasted malt and light chocolate. The mouthfeel is on the light side of medium-bodied and fairly thin yet silky soft, transitioning into a roasted, sour finish. Roasted dark and chocolate malt are complimented by a solid sweet-sour lactose note. The lactose, however, is a bit too much for my tastes. While I like this one, I enjoyed Dark Horses "One" a lot more.

Bottle from hoppymeal. Pours a very dark, oil colored black with the slightest of head. Nose is roasted malts, chocolate and molasses. Very smooth and velvety mouthfeel...the creamy milk is very evident. Flavor is less roasted than the aroma, but tons of coffee, chocolate and some darker fruits in there as well. Solid finish. Thanks hoppymeal.

12 oz bottle: Aroma is big on chocolate, toffee, malts, with some caramel and heavy cream scent to this brew.  Pours a pitch black with a small tan head the diminishes into nothing.  Taste is got a really good milky, creamy, roasted coffee note to this brew.  A bit of chocolate, light nut notes, and a bit of caramel.  The palate is awesome with the a creaminess to it that Ive never had with any other beer.  A definate good sweet stout that hits the spot right now.

12 oz. bottle.  Pours an oily black with a thin creamy tan ring.  The aroma entices with roasted malts, sweet chocolate, molasses, and some dark fruits.  The flavor is heavy on the roasted character with some coffee and chocolate in there as well.  The mouthfeel is perfect for the style; medium/full bodied and creamy smooth.  Another fine offering from Dark Horse.

Pours a very dark, almost black, brown, with a very thin, dark brown head.  Nose warms to roasty chocolate aromas.  Flavors are roast, chocolate and coffee, dominated by the roast.  Mouthfeel is medium, with fairly long lasting roast notes.  A good, if not spectacular stout.

Pours an oil black brew with a thin brown head. The aroma is sweet, molasses, coffee is a big element, dark chocolates, brown sugar. The flavor is pretty big on coffee, dark roast, light alcohol, a bittering hop presence at the back of the mouth. Molasses and brown sugars. Nice smooth palate. Excellent stout.

The color was dark chocolate black.  The head was very thin, dark tan, and creamy.  The aroma was very strong coffee, roast, sweet malt, chocolate, molasses, and vanilla.  The flavor was roasty, coffee, hops, a waxy/bitterness at the back of the mouth, and some molasses.  The flavor was not as complex as I would have like, but still good.  The palate was fairly carbonated and lively.  The finish was a waxyness.

12oz bottle.  Pour is black but a little thin looking.  Head is very faint, tan swirls here and there with a thin ring of tan cream.  Aroma is coffee roast, liquorish, and dark chocolate.  Pretty nice.  The flavor is initially sweeter and smooth; chocolaty. The roast and coffee notes appear in the finish.  The aftertaste is milky - the lactose.  The body is pretty smooth, but a little on the thin side.  I guess that is the difference between using oats for sweetness and using lactose.  I have to say I enjoy the body produced by using oats, but this lactose flavor is very nice.

(Bottle via trade with <A HREF=http://www.ratebeer.com/ViewUser.asp?UserID=3 target=blank>EithCubes, thanks Mike!) Some hiccups with this one...Pours very dark brown, like thick black coffee. Very little head. Rich, sweetish coffee/chocolate aroma. Mouthfeel fairly smooth and thick. Low carbonation. Became rather flat so palate was rather syrupy by the end. Flavor is coffee roast and dark chocolate with grassiness riding in on finish and aftertaste. More bitterness than One. First stumble Ive had from Dark Horse.

Pours Black with a fine, tan head. Aroma is roasty with chocolate overtones. Some coffee aroma in there as well. Mouthfeel is good and heavy with a roasted, coffee, chocolate flavor. Some molasses in there as well. Very good!

Solid black, just the slightest hint of a reddish-tan head.  Aroma is of milk chocolate, roasted malts and coffee.  Creamy mouthfeel.  Average carbonation, medium bodied.  Flavor is milk chocolately and smooth.  Finish is quick, slightly bitter.  Just the right amount of sweetness.  Absolutely no detectable alcohol.  Great brew.

12oz bottle. pours black with creamy tan head that didnt last that long. nose is very roasty. flavor is rich w/ roasted malts, cream, and nutty and chocolaty finish. mouth feel is right on - very creamy but not too thick or chewy. wow, really nothing to knock this beer for, just well done on all levels.

Date: 11/11/2005
Mode: Bottle
Source: Trade

pours black, headless, and oil like, no aroma, creamy roasted malt flavor, light bitterness, very boring

Aroma: 4/10; Appearance: 8/10; Flavor: 4/10; Palate: 5/10; Overall: 10/20
Rating: 2.5/5.0Drinkability: 7/10
Score: *+/4

Bottle. Lots of milk chocolate on the nose. Like Nesquik with alcohol. Malted milk chocolate ice cream. Pours almost opaque black with a tiny reddish/khaki head. Fairly dry on the palate. Definite creamy/chocolate lactose flavor. Some earthy hops begin to show after warming. Very rich and creamy on the palate.

Bottle.  Pour is solidly black and thick looking, too.  Head is fairly small and orangish brown.  Aromas are of molasses, espresso, prunes and black licorice.  Alcohol is faintly present in the nose.  Flavor is fairly spicy... I mean in addition to all of the junk you would expect from a sweet stout.  The licorice flavoring came out much stronger than in earlier samples Ive had of this.  I dont know if it is because I finally got around to rating the sixth bottle out of a six pack and it had been in the fridge for a while, or whether it was something I hadnt detected before...   Eitehr way, it adds a nice little bit of complexity to the brew that is rather particular.
user_location: The Wet Side of a Dry Town, Pennsylvania, USA

text: A nice, if not average sweet stout. Pour was a nice dark brown with a healthy 2 finger tan head. Aroma of oats and coffee. Taste of bitter coffee with a flaky sweetness and a semi thick mouthfeel. The carbonation is average and the finish is a little watery. This is a decent sweet stout.
user_location: Moon Twp, suburb of Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania, USA

text: 12oz, no date.  Black with one of the darkest mahogany heads Ive ever seen--1/2 finger and fades to a ring before too long.  Aroma of milk chocolate, roasted malts and grain, a bit of ash and vanilla.  I also got a hint of leafy herbal hops--overall fairly sweet.  Flavor is much more roasty and ashy than anticipated, though after a few more swallows the lactose makes itself a little more apparent.  Still pretty roasty with a dry ashy finish, low bitterness.  8% ABV?!?!  This tasted nowhere near that.  Medium body with very little carbonation.  A very solid sweet stout.
user_location: Ocean Beach, San Diego, California, USA

text: 12 oz bottle: poured pitch black with zero head even after an aggressive pour. Very little carbonation. Aroma is of roasted malts and chocolate. Flavor is of roasted malts with a mild bitterness. Slightly sweet, not as dry as I thought. A bit of chocolate and some coffee. Full bodied. Good but wheres the carbonation?

UPDATED: AUG 6, 2007 slightly chocolate, slightly coffee aroma. Aroma was robust.  Poured black, and I mean black! Head was small, brown and disappeared quickly leaving a very thin cap the rest of the way.  Head was creamy. Left nice lacing. Flavor, started slightly sweet, then the chocolate, caramel and coffee took over in a beautifully balanced flavor that became very slightly bitter in a pleasant way. Body is medium, texture is very creamy and smooth, very soft carbonation. Finish was a pleasantly long. What a great beer!!!  I will definitely add this to my favorite rotation of beer. A excellent beer by Dark Horse!!! If you like your beer, black as night, creamy with a nice balance of Malt, Chocolate and Coffee  this is a beer for you!

12oz bottle from EithCubes - thanks! Very similar in character to the One, with some mild but appreciable differences. Its got a nice full flavor, with somewhat less chocolate, a tad of chicory even, and a heavy bready finish. Very, very dry, which I find quite enjoyable. Id like a bit more thickness in the body, given that this is a sweet stout, as I feel that the basic qualities would benefit from this. But basically this is another impressive stout from Dark Horse.

Too weak in all regards to be a real stout. No aroma, weak body, no hops, light malt.

All-in-all a OK session brew.

toasty malt notes with out too much else. The beer pours a dark brown without any head. The flavor is pretty food but it isnt that exciting and pretty one dimensional. The mouthfeel is good and creamy.

Pours an inky black body, fairly impervious to light, under a small, oiled-leather head that settles quickly to a thick halo. Thick, dark chocolate aroma (at least 65% cacao) with the additional smooth sweetness of chocolate ice cream. Raisin, coffee roasts, cherries and light charred notes each join in from time to time. Thick, rich palate... nice and heavy with just a hint of carbonation creeping in at the end so as not to choke you. Flavor is of a high-quality chocolate covered cherry. Very few suggestions of the 8%. Roastiness joins a sweet finish for a bittersweet balance. A ton of aroma, a ton of flavor... "too" tons of fun.
<font size=-4>Single bottle from Wacky Willys... in front of <a href=http://www.ratebeer.com/Place/michigan/marsha Horse Brewing Co., , Marshall, MI 49068</font>

<>Bottle. Thanks to Artusory for the bottle. Pours a thick black body with thin head. Aroma is dark chocolate, heavy roasted malt, molasses. Taste has a heavy chocolate malt flavor, creamy, sugary, with a touch of molasses. Lightly bitter.This was very smooth. Nice thick mouthfeel. Well done.

Bottle: Dark black, creamy tan head. Light lacing, nose of sweet cocoa and roast, creamy chocolate mocha and some licorice. The flavor is wickedly dry and nuggaty with some light astringency. Marshmallow and bakers cocoa. Coffee, light roast (full city), nice. Finish is chewy, dark toffee, light spice and cinnamon, lots of cocoa. Yum.

Bottle:  Dark brown pour with a medium tan head.  Nose is coffee, roasted malt, and chocolate.  Taste is a blend of coffee and heavy roast, some bittersweet cocoa.  The coffee and roasted malt dominates, but this is flavorful.  Thanks Eithcubes.

Poured a deep, dark brown, with no real head to speak of.  Aroma was some good roasted malt with just a hint of sweetness.  While it was smooth, the taste was just off a bit.  Low carbonation, as well. Disappointing, as most of their other brews have been above average.   Ill stick with their "One".
Another one courtesy of Skyview.  Black color with no head.  To me, the aroma is closest to a dark fruit Creme Saver, like cherry.  Earthy and leathery taste.  Sweet?  No.  Tasty?  Yes.

I liked the "One" better.  This has a very malty aroma with roasted grain.  Flavor is sweet malt, and very earthy with clay and dirt.  Well balanced, very smooth palate and easy to drink.  Low carbonation.  Quite good.

12-oz. Thanks, SecretSanta! Pours a watery opaque black without a head. No lace, either. Light nose--just some perfumey licorice and a bit of char. Maybe blueberry? Watery body, flat, some ashy, almost ash-tray, business throughout the mid-palate. Seems almost like they mixed up the 2, 3, and 4 here...got elements of fruit and smoke there too. Bit disappointed given the reception this beers gotten elsewhere.
Thanks to Skyview for sharing!  Pours a dark dark brow with a sweet chocolate nose.  Light coffee flavor flavor with a smooth finish.

Picked up a single 12-oz bottle at Rileys Wines of the World in Madison, WI. Pours an opaque motor oil black brew with hardly a tan head. Aroma has dark chocolate, caramel, some coffee, and a touch of vanilla. Taste is sweet, a little acidic and a touch of bitterness. Finish is medium body, soft carbonation and bitter aftertaste.
pours an absolute black color with little or no head.  The taste is remarkably smooth.  There is a burnish smell possible of molasses.  For not being a stout lover, this one was pretty good.

From a 12oz Bottle.  Purchased at Rileys Wines of the World in Madison, WI.  Sampled immediately after One.  Pours a dark black, completely opaque color with a thin layer of quickly dissipating filmy toasted marshmellow head.  A gentle swirl sends a myriad of fine bubbles shimmering to the surface.  Very rich dark malt base thats dripping with loads of chocolates and coffee.  Some softer, fruitier notes of raisins and charred molasses add some richness.  Similar minty hop and coffee/chocolate character as with One, but the molasses chracter and softly sweet smoke are what really differentiate Too.  Medium light mouthfeel with a subtle carbonation.  Definitely needs more carbonation to help lighten up the palate some and add the namesake creaminess.  Flavors are a bit less impressive than the nose, but are solid none-the-less.  Chocolates and coffees abound up front, but these give way to some juicy dark prune and chocolate syrup.  A bit of very subtle smokey and tobacco-ish characters linger on the back-end.  Flavors are a bit less interesting to me than with the One.  Well constructed overall, with no real off traits other than the light carbonation, which isnt severe.

Poured a very dark brown with only a slight ring of froth.
Smell is heavy roasted molasses and some roasted coffee.  Taste is pretty much the same.  The mouthfeel is somewhat smoky from the roastiness.  The mouthfeel is smooth and a little lighter than medium on the mouthfeel.
A good beer, but one would be enough.  The taste does get a little much after one.

Bottle as pictured poured opaque black with the thinnest creamy brown head Ive ever seen on any stout.  A faint aroma of dry cocoa starts to rise as the brew warms.  I drank this creamy concoction right at room temperature.  I am a big fan of sweet stouts and this one did NOT disappoint. Mouthfeel was velvety smooth and flowed like Willie Wonkas chocolate river all over my taste buds!  Rich roasty flavors of cocoa and coffee w/heavy cream were savored with each sip.  The finish is a lingering chocolate combined with traces of malt that go from dry to bitter for a spendid finale.  Quite simply delicious.  I want more.

Pours black with a halloween orange head.  The aroma has lots of cream, some chocolate and smooth roasted malt.  Medium / thick body with modest carbonation.  The flavor starts with roasted malt, cream, chocolate and some char.  The finish is grainy and sharper due to hop presence.  There is a lingering milky lactic taste.  Nice beer.
Very creamy and nice.  But nothing to blow you away.  chocolate, roasty and creamy.  Almost reminiscent of a milkshake at times. Enjoyable.

Pours black with a thin brown head that fades quickly. Aroma is coffe with cream, cocoa nibs, and biscuity malt, all fairly smooth and rounded. Flavor is of weak coffee, cocoa, a little less malt then the aroma a bit sharper. Medium body, palate is a bit oily and a bit watery.
