Finishes a bit watery with aids drinkability but hinders the satisfaction of a nice velvety finish.

Thanks to beastiefan2k for this bottle - and here I thought eugene gifted me a beer Id already rated - good thing I double checked! - anyway, this beer pours an extremely dark brown, nearly black, with a medium tan, short-lived head - lots of lactose and roasted malt in the aroma, with some notes of wet wood and plum - creamy mouthfeel, with a little less body than Id like - the flavor is mostly dark coffee, anise and chocolate - the coffee flavor seems a little stale - finishes with a suprising amount of berry flavors and touches of black cherry and other dark fruit - a unique sweet stout.

Thank you, Beastiefan2k for this beer!  Dark tan head, but only around the sides of the glass after the inital pour, and a very dark brown, nearly black, oily body.  Very roasted malts and vanilla in the aroma - woody and very earthy... the alcohol is plenty-well-hidden, and I imagine that I could drink this pretty fast and easily.  Pretty strong, though, for a sweet stout.  Sweet finish, lots of lactose hanging around.  The roastiness stands out the most, and its a bit unbalanced, but decent overall.

12 oz bottle. Poured thick and oily. Color was opaque black. Head consisted of only a scant brown ring. Aroma was of dark chocolate, cream, and leather. Full bodied with a velvety smooth mouth feel troubled only by the bitter burnt stick-like roastiness. There is plenty of bitter chocolate flavor and a bit of vanilla. Delicately sweet at the end with a hint of bourbon.

12oz - Aroma of dark roasty malts, cream and a touch of chocolate.  Pours black with a small brown head and good lacing.  Flavor is stronger and roastier than aroma, very creamy.  Palate is creamy and smooth.  Tasty, but maybe a little TOO creamy for me..

Bottle.  Sweet roast aroma with chocolate (but less than One).  Light coffee.  Opaque oil black body with a light brown head.  Roast and chocolate, smooth body but a little lacking compared to their Oatmeal.  Sweet and dry roast duke it out; sweet wins.  Medium body lacks assertiveness.  Aftertaste does have a little lactose, medium malt with very light hops in the back.  Alcohol is not at all noticeable, very well integrated, but much less robustness and body than this brewer is capable of offering.

Pours a jet black with a small tan brownish tan head.  Aroma of milk chocolate, cocoa and a hint of roasted malts.  Taste is of slightly sweetened milk chocolate, baking chocolate, cocoa and smoked malt.  Nice dry finish.  Excellent.

UPDATED: OCT 23, 2007 12 oz bottle thanks to a trade with demitriustown.  Pours an oily black with a brown filmy head.  The nose is mostly molasses and burnt coffee with a little cherries and berries.  Sticky palate molasses, chocolate, tobacco, brown sugar, and a little burnt with a nice bitterness in the finish.  A nice stout from dark horse.

really good for a cream stout.  pours a dark rouge black color with a red head that quickly disappears.  sweat milk chcolate, juniper berries, fruit tannins and cherry play on the nose and tongue.  hits the tip of the tongue heavy but quickly fades.

12 oz bottle via trade, but with whom I am unsure.  Pours black with a reddish brown head.  The aroma is big with creamy goodness in it.  The taste is light sweet and crreamy.  It is certainly good, great, not so sure, but very good.

Bottle.  Dark brown head on a black body - good lookin stuff!  Roasty malt aroma with a detectable lactose sweetness - standard (but appealing) stuff for a sweet stout.  Classic sweet stout flavors - chocolaty roast, some dark berry, lactose sweetness with just a hint of hop bitterness in the finish.  Smooth, velvety mouthfeel.  Nothing wrong with a good sweet stout!

tap at the brewpub - Pours black with a medium sized tan head.  It has a light roast malt aroma.  The flavor is a very nice darkly roasted/toasted malt with good mild hops balance and some chocolate notes.  This brew is full bodied and feels lightly carbonated on the palate, which I like.  I wouldnt have guessed that this one had 8% abv.

A solid sweet stout  sugary and roasty, velvet mouthfeel. Poured black with a thin, dark tan head that quickly disappeared. Nose filled with roasted malts, bitter chocolate, coffee. Flavor is sweet with a roast bitterness in the finish that lingers. Medium to full bodied. Creamy texture. Minimal carbonation. Lasting finish. Enjoyable.

Thanks to sliffy for this one via Mystery Swap 2.0.   I liked this one a tad more than the One, but they are both world class stouts.  The pour here is jet black with tan head.  Aroma of big roasty, oaty dark malt, dark chocolate syrup, molasses.  Tastes roasty dark malty, oaty, with a solid dark chocolate element, plus mild coffee notes, slight nuts.  Rich palate, albeit a tiny bit dry for this style.  This one is outstanding.

UPDATED: DEC 19, 2012 12 oz bottle courtesy of MI2CA.  Poured into a small tulip glass with small brown head. Again the blackest color. Aroma is soft roastiness, emphasis on soft.  I get lactose but more like spoiled cider and a prune juice aspect.  Mouthfeel is undercarbonated which adds to the prune juice similarity. Taste is just slightly spoiled milk, weird fruitiness (did I say prune enough), and finishes with slight coffee bitterness, which stays for the aftertaste.  The hinting coffee leaves me wanting more, the undercarbonation is not too desirable and this beer is my first disappointment of the 4 stout beers (maybe my expectations were too high).
I am thinking the original rating was an off bottle.  Bought this at a store in North Chicago.  Poured completely black with a dark brown, large head.  Still looks good.  The bottom line on this beer is its all bitter malt, not a sweet stout at all.  I feel like I am smelling burning stove and drinking bitter black patent husk. Too one dimensional.  Alcohol well hidden.
user_location: HdG (past: NYC, KS, Rain City), Maryland, USA

text: This pours nearly black with a very small brown head. This brew is lightly carbonated with a medium/thin body. The flavor is of lightly roasted nuts and some chocolate.

Bottle from ogglethorp; nose of roasty coffee and bittersweet chocolate; opaque black with only a few cinnamon colored bubbles; Nice thick body, but little carbonation; flavor of coffee, roastiness, light sweetness, and some chocolate. Excellent flavor, needs more gas!

Little head retention on this black beast.  The pour opens up notes of milk chocolate, heavy cream, bitter chocolate and lightly roasted coffee.  Silky texture plays off low carbonation making this liquid velvet. A little more CO2 would be nice to help define the roasted malts. The coffee becomes more pronounced in the body, cut nicely by the sweetness of the lactose.  Very drinkable and mind boggling how they crammed enough malt into this to get to 8%.

Bottle thanks to ogglethorp!  Pours a deep, deep, deep brownish/black with an extremely dense brown head.  Nice roasty aromas, bitterness.  Nice flavor but a bit or an odd aftertaste, sort of chalky and medicinal.  Great mouthfeel and a nice finish.  Overall a good beer.
user_location: The Land of Milk and Honey, Ohio, USA

text: Lovely aroma. Not immediately in love with it, but by the second sip, I liked it more. Roasty flavor, with a bit of sweetness. Long chocolate finish. Nice body. I would appreciate a bit more carbonation (almost none to speak of), but it doesnt ruin the beer at all.

12oz bottle, courtesy of artusory.  Thanks, Ryan!  Pours a dark black core, medium tan head with patchy retention at the edges.  Marshmallow and roasted malts in the aroma, hints of milk chocolate.  Medium-to-full mouthfeel: milk chocolate, wet and roasted malts; pleasant, citrus hop bitterness balancing things out.  Long, creamy and milk chocolate finish.

Nice thick black pour, very little head save for a few tan bubbles at the edges.  Sweet chocolate aroma, hint of coffee.  Moderately thick mouthfeel.  Nice smooth roast chocolate flavor with a mild sour turn at the end from the lactose.  Couldve used some extra body, but this was still very good.

dark horse knows how to make a sexy looking stout. thick black great dark brown head. great job. probably the best smelling of any cream/milk stout i have had. most smell like spoiled milk. not this one. very nice coffee with cream aroma also a hint of campfire wood smoke. the milk flavor isnt overbearing it brings a very nice sweet creamy balance to the bitter coffee flavor. bittersweet creamy coffee finish with a medium dry end. medium body. smooth but seems a bit thin. with a bit more weight i would have easily given the palate a 5. straightforward but very nice. hands down the best milk stout i have had thus far.

UPDATED: NOV 1, 2007 Bottle, poured black with a few bubbles, I could count them on one hand, roasted malt and sweet rise to the nostrils, hint of chocolate, dark chocolate and vanilla, some bitter chocolate and coffee fragrances, roasted malt and chocolate flavors, light bite in each drink, smooth on the palate, a touch thin in the mouth otherwise a nice drink.

Bottle from Silphium. Definitely creamy, slightly thick, but overall a little boring. Nose has a nice lactic sweetness -- usually the milk is kinda nasty smelling -- and a touch of roast. Pour is dead boring. Flavor is similar, slightly milky, dry, creamy. Tasty.

Thanks to Silphium for the bottle. Black with an almost nonexistent head. Aroma of coffee and creamy chocolate. Sweet taste, mainly, with a hint of bitterness. Medium to heavy body. Flat carbonation. Creamy texture.

Very deep brown/near black pour. Quickly dissipating extremely dark brown head. This beer has a surprisingly light nose, but is chock full of beefy roastiness, fresh-brewed coffee, bittersweet caramel and chocolate. A very balanced and standout aroma. Upon first sip, all I can conjure up is "Dark Horse is such a fun brewery, good beer too." Nice heavy roastiness sets in soon thereafter. Also adorning my tastebuds with their respective flavors are light smokiness, chocolate, caramel, coffee, cookie. The palate is a little thinner than Id like, medium-light to medium, moderately bitter. The best part is yet to come: an amazingly delicious chocolate chip cookie finish, just like a liqueur produced from fine exotic ingredients. A winner from Dark Horse.

Black. Small, dense, brown layer of foam. Aroma of roasted bitterness, subtle chocolate and vanilla, whole coffee beans, big time dark chocolate as it warms. Flavor of huge chocolate chips, subtle coffee, same roasted bitterness, subtle vanilla, cookie malt, and some light hops in the finish and aftertaste. Medium, balanced body. Easy drinking. Id like a little more weight in the body. Still very good.

Roasty aroma with some burnt sugar sits atop a fairly flat, black beer with little light brown head.  Rich and creamy with lots of velvet and roasted goodness. Rather limp, with a milky, sweet chocolate flavor.  well balanced and very tasty.  These guys do great stouts!  Thanks Brad.

12oz bottle from Artusory. This dark brown ale poured with a miniscule tan head, eliciting a strong chocolate espresso aroma.  This one is very tasty, though somewhat flat. The most prominent flavor is bitter chocolate, but there is also a noticeable coffee presence. There is a very thick slightly bitter finish that sticks to your tongue.

12 oz bottle.  Pours a brief but beautiful crema head atop dark espresso.  Dark chocolate and coffee.  Prominent bourbon alcohol.  Melt some bittersweet chocolate, add 8 shots of espresso, some cane sugar, vanilla, half cup cream and a squirt of lime and youll get an idea of how tasty this stout is.  Silky and rich with just enough back end drying to chase off remaining lactic sweetness.  Ready for another sip.  TOO good!

Pours very black with not much of a tan head at all. I could smell the aroma from over a foot away from the glass, smelled very chocolatey and roasty. The aroma close to the glass is very similar but it seems to be a little more bitter chocolate. Flavor was a little bitter on the tongue, seems to be from chocolate and hops. Very smooth and sweet in the mouth. I didnt notice the 8% in this at all.

Bottle. Pours a pitch black color with a small tan head. Aroma of roasted coffee beans, semi sweet chocolate and smokey. Has a bit of a woody, oak aged flavor to it. This is a very smooth cream stout that finishes slightly dry and with a hint of fermented fruit in the aftertaste. This is a very nice, complex  Cream Stout that can hold its on with any out there.

UPDATED: FEB 20, 2008 From the bottle- Pours a pitch black color, dark brown head. This looks delicious. The nose is very sweet, some slight coffee and chocolate notes. Drinking this is sweet, great mouthfeel, roasted/coffee notes. Smooth creamy finish. Incredibly luxurious and finely made.
Smooth, mellow, roasty, almost smoky malt taste with standard chocalate/coffee note. Sort of flat. The cream/lactic aspect doesnt quite work, especially in the finish. medium body.

THANKS BREWBLACKHOLE!!!  Dark color.  Smell of malt, hops, heavy coffee, nuts and chocolate.  Taste of hops, roasted coffee, caramel, hints of chocolate and sugar.  A strong coffee bitterness at the end.  I like my stouts thick and rich and its lacking in this one!  Still enjoyable.  I really like the coffee that comes out in  this.

The beer is a deep dark brown - very nearly black - with a thin film ring along the edge. Other than a few flecks of foam here and there, it doesnt leave any lace, but rather thick, oily legs. Moderate roasted malt aroma, slightly fruity.

Not surprisingly, the flavor is dominated by roasted malt - full-flavored yet mellow. Behind this is a little bit of sweeter malt, and a generic hop bitterness in the finish. A pleasant bitter chocolate and dark roast coffee flavor shows up in the aftertaste - slightly smokey. Medium body, lightly carbonated, fairly smooth mouthfeel.

UPDATED: FEB 11, 2007 I am rerating this brew, the first one was a bit watery,I have since been told that there was a minor problem at the brewery,and that a few undercarbonated brews got out,the second one I had was much better,silky mocha chocolate in the aroma, a tastey heavily milked chocolate coffee in the taste,with roasted and hop bitterness in the finish,still atouch thin,but much better then the first

Bottle shared by sliffy. Pitch black pour with no real head to speak of, just specks of tan along the edges. Nice strong aroma of darkchcolate, pungent coffee, light raspberry elements and some roasted malts.  Flavaors of bakers chocolate, roasted malts, and coffee came through. Velvety mouthfeel, roasty and toasty throughout with a roast/bitter/dry finish. Good stuff!

Coffee, chocolate and some ash tray in the aroma.  Deep black in color with a nice chocolate brown head.  The palate is thin for a stout.  Chocolate malts and coffee up front with a slight bitterness in the end--and some of that ash tray flavor makes its way into the finish and stays on your tongue.

Bottle: Black with a very small tan head. Aroma of coffee, chocolate, and roasted malts. Flavor, chocolate, some coffee, some bittersweet notes, and a smooth creamy mouthfeel. These guys just seem to do stouts well.
Aroma is chocolate and coffee.Pours black with tan head.Smooth chocolate with lots of coffee and a bit of alcohol in the flavor.A little thin but a smooth creamy finish.

12 oz bottle
I got this in a recent trade with artusory.  It was very well made.  If only there was not a neverending supply of new beers to try, I would pick this one up if it ever made it to Madison.  As it is, I can highly recommend it if you find it while in Michigan.
Aroma / Appearance - It pours a dark plum color that behaves like an oily liquid.  The lacing clings to the side of the glass before sliding down to rejoin the rest.  The nose is an intruiging combination of burnt toast, smores, plums, blueberries and cedar chips.  In the background is a hint of chocolate (the cheap waxy candy bar type).
Flavor / Palate - Sweet chocolate chips, roasted malts, smoke and raisins present themselves from the start.  After that comes a chalky chocolate mouthfeel that is a little thin but still pleasing.  The aftertaste is malty and slightly bitter.  This is very easy to drink and was gone before I knew it.  While not extremely complex, it still is good enough to warrant a recommendation if you can find it.

Bottle from Bello Vino, Ann Arbor. Deep ruby-black with a small milk-chocolate brown head. Aroma is fantastic - lots of roast and cocoa, some fresh coffee, a touch of sour cherry, and an interesting smoky & salty end note. Body is a bit thin, but nice, giving it an almost cask-like character. Flavour isnt quite as impressive as the aroma, but is still pretty nice - good roastiness with a bit of chocolate, and a bitter finish that lengthens as it warms up. Very nice stout.

Bottle thanks to Styles!  Poured a deep, viscous black with a beautiful cap of rich mahogany head.. unfortunately it didnt last too long.  Deeply-roasted, almost burnt dark chocolate, lactose sweetness, a bit of cherry, and coffee in the aroma.. very nice.  Excellent in the flavor department, too... dry roasted dark chocolate and coffee at the forefront, coffee bitterness, lactose sweetness and dried cherries on the middle, and a long, sweet roasted coffee finish.  Medium-bodied and on the thin side (compared to how the pour looked)... decent balance.. somewhat grainy at times... dry roasty finish.  Excellent brew!  Thanks Chris!

Black body with a chocolate head that fades. Mild roast, dark bitter chocolate that hints at black coffee. Dry flavour up front, sweet malt middle, lingering dry coffee like patent malt (?) bitterness. Flavour gets a a bit sweeter as the glass goes on. Average palate is a bit thin for a stout with cream in the name, needs a bit more bodyin my opinion. Decent stout that did little for me.

[013-20060828] 341mL. Gamey syrup aroma. Black body with small, disappearing, light brown head. Some chocolate, roasted coffee flavouring, but fairly smooth. Full mouth feel. Definitely stouty, not creamy.

Bottle shared with HogTownHarry & tupalev -- courtesy of HogTownHarry. Pours black with a spare diminishing brown head. Aroma of deep roasted malt, cofee, dark chocolate and hops -- quite nice. Flavour follows the aroma -- sweet and bitter. Medium bodied. Pretty good, Ive yet to have a bad Dark Horse beer.

Bottle, shared with Blankboy and Hogtown Harry, Harrys bottle.  Pitch black, very dark small head.  Really good aroma:  wonderful roast.  Wow - bad taste. Boo!  Tinny, thin roast, too sweet.  So thin!  Better on second sip - roast and sweetness balances out a bit more.  Still though, disappointing thin taste overall.

Bottle (12oz).  Shared with blankboy and tupalev, my bottle.  Thick black pour, minimal dark brown head (really want to give it a 4).  Extremely deep dark roast aroma, dry, strong acidic coffee, bitter nutshellm hint of dark cherry, some dry hops in there too.  Taste is roasty, sweet deep molasses malt, nut bitterness, coffee - decent finish.  Thickish body, not much carbonation, nicely acidic.  Pretty good.

Draft sample at MBGF. Black color with a medium frothy brown head that lasted with good lacing. Heavy roasted malt aroma. Medium  to full body with a creamy texture. Medium dark chocolate roasted flavor with a roasted finish of long duration. Better than my expectations.
Thick, quiet dark pour with almost no head. Rich, roasted character, strong coffee like nose. Smooth, creamy texture with well accented roasted grain. Neat, drinkable stout.

Bottle. Deep black with a small mocha head. Aroma is creamy roast, gobs of coffee, dark bitter chocolate, and dark fruits. The flavour is very chocolatey and roasty with bitter green hops, cookies, and soft toastiness. Another nice one from Dark Horse.
Strong coffee nose, with some big chocolate notes, black, full coffee flavour, some mocha/cream and caramel too. Full bodied, rich bitterness. Extremely good! Thank You mds.

Bottle: Black body with a small tan head.  Aroma is roasted barley, prunes, light sweet, along with some faint cocoa.  Taste is roasted malts, prunes, chocolate, coffee.  Light-medium bodied, slightly watery, moderate carbonation.

Bottle... Pitch black ale with a small, creamy, light brown head. The rich nose is all about chocolate, black cherries, caramel and smoke. Well-balanced flavor. Chocolatey and burnt, but not bitter. Medium-bodied with a creamy mouthfeel and soft carbonation. Finishes roasty and dry. Thanks go out to artusory for sharing the bottle!

(12oz bottle) Small brown head with motor-oiol body.  Aroma is moderately sweet, cocoa, some coffee, faint mint.  Taste is sweet, cocoa, roast, some grapefruit/earthy, light coffee.  Watery medium body -- surprisingly light for the ABV.
12oz. bottle. Black color with a small tan head. Dark roasted malt aroma with lots of milk chocolate and a bit of coffee. Flavor was chocolate, roasted malt, vanilla and some lactic tartness.

Pours black with a dirt colored head.  Aroma is subtle with sweet chocolate and cream.  Flavor is quite bitter and acidic from coffee...sweet and sour fruits.  Mouthfeel is moderately carbonated, drying, and a bit sticky.

Definitely a lot richer and thicker than the ONE in flavor and body.  Smoky malts, chocolate, and alcohol in the aroma.  Black color with some brown head.  Flavor is pretty smoky and chocolate.  Alcohol is not as noticeable as the ONE.  Better.

smells kinda like the one, with massive alcohol on the front end.  none of these have much head, but this is pretty good looking.  pretty sweet aroma too, not necessarily something i look for in a sweet stout, but still its good.  a lot less alcohol flavor than the One given the same abv.  not a whole lot going on still.  quite a bit of bitterness in the cofee roasts.  finish is pretty decent.
Very dark. Chocolate, coffee and molasses are present in the flavor. The abundance of roasted malt and barley give it a pleasing smoky finish, witj warming alcohol.
And it is Dark.  Very little head.  Lots and lots of roasted malt in aroma and taste.  Chocolate and coffee is also present.  Sweet, but not too sweet.

12oz bottle shared courtesy of weeare138. Poured a dark black color with a small sized off white head. Aromas of chocolate, roast, and vanilla. Tastes of stronger chocolate, coffee, vanilla, roast, and has a light smokiness to it.

Poured an opaque black color with a small, dark tan head that left light lacing on the glass.  Aroma of roasted malts, chocolate, smoke, and some dried fruits.  Taste of tons of chocolate, some smoke, light vanilla, and a dry roastiness, capped off by a touch of alcohol in the finish.
UPDATED: APR 14, 2006 Thanks to weeare138.  Pours a dark brown with barely any head.  Aroma of coffee, chocolate, lactose and caramel.  Flavor of coffee, dark chocolate and lactose.

12 oz bottle from Bello Vino in Ann Arbor, MI (December 2005), released into a Unibroue glass at cellar temperature.  Pours inky, utterly black with a very small, diminishing quite dark head....bitter, roasty dark chocolate, licorice and burnt molasses in the surprisingly rough and strong nose....very thick and oily on the tongue, with little carbonation, which to my taste suits the burnt, roasty character in the flavor pretty well:  dark unsweetened chocolate, cowboy coffee are the usual suspects along with dry pine and charred oak, the blackened grain really seeming prominent as well....this is quite excellent, but doesnt really seem to fit the sweet stout categorization....until it gets fairly warm,  when a fair amount of vanilla & sweeter cocoa show up towards the finish.....though even then they are muted and almost disappear under the roasty onslaught.

Not much of a browqn head on this this black ale, but who cares?  Nice roasted aroma full of roasted barley and malt, chocolate, vanilla, burnt wood, coffee, and a hit of almond bitterness.  All that is there in the flavor with the merest trace of the sturdy abv.  Nice bittersweet finish.  Had I been told that this this was an Imperial, I would have responded, "And a damned fine one, too."<font size=-4>By <a href=http://www.ratebeer.com/ViewUser.asp?UserID=1 gracious generosity.<font size=-1>

Thanks Nancy (mamabeer) and Tom!  This beer has a nicely developed aroma of vanilla, coffee, and toffee.  It is black with a dark brown head that fades fast.  This beer has a nice robust coffee taste that is both bitter and sweet.  It fades a tad bitter as the coffee taste settles on the throat to be enjoyed well after swallowing.

Bottle.  Pours pitch black with dark brown head.  Heavy on the roasts and coffee along with bitter chocolate and charcoal.  Finishes with a nice lingering bitterness.  ABV completely hidden.  Another fine brew from these guys.

Black as night pour topped by a thin brown head that dissapates quickly.   Chocolate and coffee and roasted malts in the nose.   Chocolate/vanilla/honey/almonds/and chocolate milk in flavor.   Big ABV so well hidden as to be non-existant.   Very lightly bittered.   Very reminiscent of Founders Breakfast Stout, maybe even better!
Pours black, with a brown head. Aromas are coffee, roasted malt, chocolate, and hops. Flavors are roasted malt, coffee, hops, and chocolate. A little too bitter, bu pretty good.

12 oz. bottle thanks to Silphium.  Pours midnight black with a sparse dark head that faded quickly.  Aromas were come dark chocolate, and mocha.  Flavor coffee first and some backing chocolate competeing with a hop finish.  Roastiness throughout and tasty stuff.

12 oz bottle via trade with SuIIy!  - Thanks Mike!  - Pours black and thick with a nice creamy mocha head that laces the glass in thick layers.  Looks exactly like a good stout should.  Aroma is milk chocolate, much roasted character too though.  A touch of coffee also can be found above the glass.   Flavor is roasted malt, milk chocolate, smoke, coffee, a little caramel.  Very decadant.  Palate is smooth with a somewhat oily feel.  Lingering sweet aftertaste keeps you coming back for more.  Full bodied and the alcohol is covered well.  Very nice...
Pour is opaque black with a crazy dark brown head...smell is sweet and creamy chocolate...taste is sweet and toasty cocoa with a great mouthfeel...alcohol is not noticable at all...nice one...

Thanks to MikeMac: Nice sweet brew. Poured black, with a nice mahogony head.  A litte high alcohol for a sweet stout, but you would never know if by the taste.  I nice sweet milky chocolate taste... not overbaring on the sweetness though...

This poured much darker then expected, like motor oil.  Very icky sweet aroma, like milk.  This reminds me of a milk stout.  Rich and creamy.  A fine beer after a meal, but I wouldnt want a lot of it at one time.  Should be enjoyed with a fine cigar. Finishes with a roasted milky sweetness that makes you want to take another sip.  I would recommed this to someone who has not had a stout to try this.  Not your adverage Guiness...brillant!
Pours black with medium, fading,  creamy tan head. The aroma is sweet chocolate, some smoke and coffee. The flavor is rich, creamy, milk chocolate. The mouthfeel is smooth and creamy.

12 oz bottle, via Styles.  Pours black as motor oil with almost no head.  Large yeast deposit on bottom of bottle.  Deep coffee nose with bitter chocolate and lactose.  Flavor is roasted malt with tons of coffee up front.  Finish is milk chocolate with lighter roastiness.  Very sweet overall.  Full bodied with a velvety mouthfeel, minimal carbonation.  My third beer from these guys and they have all been awesome.  Im wondering if these guys cornered the market on black patant malt, cause all three have been the color of motor oil.  Great beer.

From Styles.  Pours to a thick looking black body with a thick really dark brown head.  The aroma is very roasty and malty.  Mostly coffee, chocolate, lactose, and strong grass hops.  The flavor is a charred roasty chocolate malt.  I like this beer a lot.  The palate is creamy, medium-light bodied, dry charcoal feel.  Damn tasty.

(bonus brew by way of styles)this cream stout poured a used motor oil black with very little dark brown head.the aroma was of burnt coffee beans,cocoa,chocolate,and roasted malts.the falvor was a mix of milk,cocoa,and more burnt coffee.the alcohol was VERY hidden and the mouthfeel was on the light side.

Dark black pour a small dark brown head w/ some decent lacing.  Very big roasty malt aroma some coffee notes.  Full palate well coated and lightly creamy a little thicker and it would be a five.  Taste is amazing.. Full roasty flavor good roasted malt some nice smooth chocolate feels a little velvety a touch of light bitterness in the finish and hints of coffee in the aftertaste.. Very very good stout.

Thanks again, Santa!  Another beer from a brewery I probably would not have heard about were it not for secret Santa.  Dark with dark brown head.  Strong aroma of coffee, roasted malts, some chocolate.  Very smooth and thick in the mouth; taste is smoky and coffee, slightly bitter, but mostly balanced.  Very tasty!

12oz bottle. Pours a nice dark brown color with a very small light brown head. Very opaque. Lots of big roasty malt, chocolate and coffee here, some light toffee as well. A nice thick mouth feel, very roasty and coffee like with a smooth "creamy" finish. Nice bitterness and fizzyness in the end.
Pours black with nice tan head that fades rather quickly. Some milk chocolate, vanilla and raosted grain in the aroma. Flavor much the same with some dry roasted coffee in the finish.

UPDATED: DEC 13, 2005 2004 bottle from Crosling, thanks so much Nick, this kicked ass!  Consumed on 12/4/05.Pours a deeply opaque, black as night colored body with a seriously burnt tan-coal colored head that I manage to get about a cover out of before it quickly runs for the edges and then nothing.You know, normally this would elicit about a 2 out of me for appearance, but is the appearance in a stout so important?? No, not really.  Here it just signifies that it is nearly flat, and that is not a bad thing, I certainly dont care for highly carbonated beers.  If it was a pilsner or something similar, than appearance and carbonation are a little more indicative of quality, to some extent, but not here.  Not to mention, I just know this would be a 4 or 5 for appearance when fresh.Moving on.  The aroma pleasures the nostrils with thick, rich vanilla beans, creamy milk chocolate, light hazelnut-chocolate spread and thick barley notes.  Light, drying yeast is noted as well.  What it is light on is the roast and hops, which is fine with me, and a welcomed departure from your more traditional stout.  But the vanilla, chocolate, light bitter black chocolate and thick cocoa and dry yeast is well pronounced and soothing.  The flavor continues with the chocolate, though it is less bitter and black and more like a sweet honeyish-chocolate mixed in with vanilla iced cream.  Succulent and well-placed lightly dry barley grain notes on the sides of the palate, adding balance and a light touch of coffee as it warms, sort of a grainy mocha or coffee-bean touch.  The texture is fluid, immensely velvety and soothing, very near flat, but not thin or watery, importantly.  The liquid glides down the throat leaving a pleasant sensation of light bitterness, sweet vanilla and brown malts lingering on the back of the throat.  No alcohol apparency whatsoever.  Medium body and very drinkable.At 8 abv, this is nowhere near overdone, overhopped, syrupy, overly bitter, that sort of thing and that factors much in my score.  Highly flavorful without being overdone.

Thick, oozing black pour and undeniably opaque.  Precious few dust speckles on the surface, but otherwise, darkness prevails.  Aroma is so fin good.  Singed hazelnuts, bitter espresso sludge, piney tar grooves, dark unsweetened chocolate bricks and muddy, trampled clay hiking trails.  Flavor is lighter faring than expected, but tasty in its own right, settling in with cocoa powder and Irish cream flavored coffee grinds.  Roastiness pursues post sip, somewhat enigmatic to the superfluous cafe motif.  Juxtaposition of dry buttercream and whipped chocolate torte fluff aid in the full circle, medium bodied display, which is synchronistical creamy and dry.  Not a heavy hitter, but tasty by all means.  At times - and most prevalent in the finish - we get an airy forkload of tiramisu, ringing with a layer of coffee grinds and trailing long after the sun sets (which has long deserted us in Wisconsin by this time of year.)  HUGE thanks to Styles for the bottle!

Drank after a night of coffee, bottle, somewhat cold.  Aroma of roasted malt and some bitter hops came through. than I expected.  Small dark head, some lacing.  Taste is sweet with a good amount of coffee and chocolate notes.  slightly fruity aspect to the taste.  Texture was very creamy, just enough carbonation.  finished bitter with chocolate, although on a few sips i swear it tasted like lettuce.  Good choice for a cold winter night.

Shared this with Duane.  Started drinking this after it warmed up a bit and the aroma is pretty intense.  Roasted malts, raisins/prunes, some alcohol all coming through in the nose.  Taste is much the same with some sweetness as well as a slightly bitter chocolate finish.  I dont know if I could drink a whole bottle of this, but this is a good one.

Dark Horse makes some outstanding beers!  nose is of dark chocolate and some plum/raisins.  appearance is jet black with a brownish ruby head.  up front the flavors are of mild dark chocolate with some dark roast malt and a hint of coffee.  on the finish is a lingering bitterness that is not unpleasant at all.  Michigan stouts rock!  thanks to Walleye for this 12 oz. bottle.

UPDATED: APR 17, 2006 Appears a black color with a foamy tan head. Lots of scaly lacing all over the glass.
Smell is very creamy, with chocolate, roasted malt, and vanilla.
Taste is of the same aromas. Pretty darn good.
Mouthfeel is roasty, full bodied, mildly sweet and filled with a coffee bitterness that is mostly pleasant.
Drinkability is nice. Very good brew.

Opaque black color, just as every single Dark Horse stout, but with a thin, and quickly diminishing light tan head.  Espresso and chocolate aromas, with hints of vanilla, roast and brownies, quite the vibrant little blend of malt aromatics.  Flavor has some oxidation, just like the aroma, but this is also a 2004 example.  Body is slightly undercarbonated and it is thin, but not watery.  Slightly bitter and astringent malt, but still decadent and enjoyable, with chocolate and cream flavors.  Quite the treat.

from the bottle. poured black, with a tan head. aroma sweet dark chocolate, , coffee, caramel, cocoa. flavor the blend of the chocolate and coffee was right on for me than got those nice roasted malts. a little on the chaulky side but good. this is the 2nd dark brew from dark horse I have had, got one more to go and I am looking forward to it

Extremely dark black. Chocolaty-sweet nose. Rich, intense, dark chocolate flavors. Silky-soft texture was real nice, but it was a little lacking in the carbonation department. Sweet notes of creamy milk, cocoa and caramel. Background aromas of smoke and tobacco. Overall: Great aromas; OK flavors; questionable texture. Oh, and I wasnt fond of the multi-phallic label, for what thats worth. What is that a drawing of anyway?

Virtually no head.
Body is black, potentially opaque (not flashlight tested).

Aroma is moderately malty (coffee, chocolate, caramel), with a note of vanilla.

Flavor is moderately sweet, lightly acidic, lightly bitter.
Finish is lightly sweet, moderately acidic, moderately bitter.

Medium body, watery texture, soft carbonation, lightly alcoholic.

Starts out ok in the nose, but falls down a bit in the mouth...not much body or texture, and kind of tart.

Dark red color, no head. Fantastic aroma- creamy mocha, rich and roasty malts. Taste is huge roasted coffee and malts. Slight oxidation really throws this beer off though. Body is watery. Tobacco finish.

Bottle pours an extremely dark black with only a suggestion of a light brown head. Aorma is roasted and a bit of molassas and slightly sour.  More like a very strong porter.  Flavor is similar.  Dark roasted notes and a little chocolate but mainly that burnt, charcoal flavor.  Again I thought rather porter-ish.  A rather thin fell as well. The late aftertaste is a quite strong smokey bitter.  I expected more "sweet" or "cream" in this one.
Nice but a bit over rated I thought. 
Thanks to pailhead for this sample of the midwest.

Thanks to Pailhead for this one. Massive coffee and  malt aroma. Pours deep black with no real head. Rich dark bakers chocolate flavors followed by coffee. Other than a marked lack of roastiness this doesnt feel like a sweet stout. Mouthfeel is very creamy so no false advertising here.

(Bottle, courtesy of Pailhead)   Pours an opaque black oily body with a ravishing  caramel brown head.  Aroma of coffee, roasted malt, and caramel.  Flavor of coffee, roasted malt, chocolate, and some breadiness.

Aroma:  hay and stable scents, with some thick grain alcohol and motor oil combined with some red grapes, some light plastic (like kids toys), and some flowers

Appearance:  very thick, very dark (dark brown-->black, tan head, lacing

Flavor:  smoke, semi-sweet chocolate, roasted/burnt malts, some sweet wine tastes (tannins?) or red grape skins

Palate:  very smooth, light red grape skin aftertaste combined with some taste that coats the inside of the mouth (a mixture of semi-sweet chocolate and smokiness I think)

Overall:  better tasting than it smells for sure

A contrast to the One Oatmeal Stout that we just opened... this one is thicker, looking (and smelling) like motor oil, with a firm dark brown, almost caramel colored head on top.  Nose is full of fuesel-like alcohol, blackened shoe polish and oil, caramel chews and some scotch.  Quite weird, I guess.  Up front its silky smooth, but turns to a caustic and abrasive prickliness over the back of the tongue... chalky residue covers the mouth afterwards, which isnt entirely pleasent.  Black smoke is what I think of when the flavors hit me... some butterscotch and white bread (grains?) as well.  An interesting beer, but head-to-head the One Oatmeal Stout wins easily.

About as good interpretation of the cream stout style as I have sampled ... equal with Bells Double Cream.  Very little co2 go on and just a hint of a head.  The roasted and coffee notes are big in the aroma.  Nice smooth feel in the mouth.  Beauty.

Bottled. Poured with a completely black body. Almost no head. The aroma is rich caramel and smoky bubblegum. The taste is roasted walnuts with wood. There is also a strong note of very dark chocolate. The mouthfeel is slick and smooth. A very solid brew. Dark Horse deserves a lot of praise, especially for their darker and bigger brews.

Oil slick black, small tan creamy head.  Rich nose of smokey milk chocolate, ash, espresso, and caramel mocchiato.  Straight up burnt citrus fruit bitterness flavors kick it off on the first sip, followed up quickly by a light smokiness. All these flavors get completely encompassed by tones of Godiva chocolate liquor notes throughout.  Medium bodied and syrupy, cask carbonation, chocolate espresso like finish.  A fantastic stout that yet again is another gem from these guys...

Thanks, I got this in a trade, and I can not for the life remember from who, you know who you are, and, I really must thank you, sorry about the props.....
Poured so dark and so thick, it was the proverbial molasses in winter. The head was tight and DARK brown. The aroma was roasted malts, and chocolate.  The carbonation was only enough to add to the flavors, that were, again, thick ass hell man. This is sweet and yummy. Bitter chocolate and coffee and all creamy, this was excellent. GET THIS!

Thanks to Styles for this.This is really,really dark with the thinnest of rings of mohagany bubbles around the glass.Aroma is like the bitter chocolate used in flourless tortes in some expensive restaurants.And roasted coffee beans.This is a good beer.Flavor is cery good as the chocolate isnt overdone but man can you taste the bitter chocolate.This is like chocolate dessert and a cup of fresh coffee.

Bottle pours a thick black, quite opaque, smal brown milk froth like head, with fairly attractive lacing.   Wow, this is some dark stuff.   Roasted malts, campfire, coffee beans, and slight bittersweet chocolate on the nose.   This seems almost too hearty to be a sweet stout.   A very slight lactic like sweetness is also noticable.   Fairly smooth, albeit light, lactose like stout flavor up front.   Quite hearty too...   While smooth, it still seems somewhat thin.   Body isnt all that big, and the mouthfeel could use a bit more umph.   However, it is rather slick/smooth on the tongue.   Finishes sweet, like black coffee with mucho milk but with little sugar.   A strong Sweet Stout for sure.   Thanks goes out to jtw for the trade!

Opaque, black body with a burgundy tone and loose brown head. Rich, creamy nose of dark chocolate and roast. Flavor brings more roast with elements of coffee and burnt raisins. Has a balance of medium sweetness and acidity. Oily texture. A tasty stout, but lacks depth.

Thick rich pour of opaque black liquid.  Ring of tan bubbles line the outer rim of the glass. Aromas of blackberries, dark cocoa, and a hint of coffee oil. Rich aroma. Thick fell that gets thinned out by something a bit acerbic. Wish the flavors matched better with the aromas. Thinner flavors of coffee, with a thin raspberry syrup, mild sourdough and dark rye bread. Really mellow as it warms. Looks like another Michigan brewer is looking to be a top brewer of stouts.
Black color with a large dark brown head. Nice roasted coffee, bourbon, plum, lactose and smoke aroma and flavor. Very creamy feel.

Deep, dark black color...opaque...with a large, ultra creamy brown head (this thing looks amazing!) The aroma was filled with chocolate, vanilla, smoke, spearmint/wintergreen, and a slight lactic sourness. The flavor was full of chocolate, lactic sourness, slight smoke, and a hint of vanilla. The feel was incredibly smooth...wet/coating finish. Awesome sweet stout. Thanks Wohlfs!!!

A very dark stout, poors a guniess color with slight amber tones, cream comes through during last mouth feel, aquuired this bottle at a beer shop in jackson, never been to the brewerey would like to go. An excellent brew.

12 oz bottle-HUGE HUGE thanks to Wolfhs for sending this beer my way in a trade.  Pours a wonderful pitch black hue that was oily and thick during the pour.  Black as hell!  An awesome dark brown head toped this beer.  A very robust aroma-complex with notes of roast, smoke, currants, maple surup, dark chocolate, plums, char-absolutely wonderful!  Awesome flavors of columbian coffee, roast, smoke, burnt notes, dark chocolate, plum, rum.  Pure stout bliss!  This could be the most under-rated beer on rate beer.  TO me, this is a top 50 all the way!  Long roasty, smokey chocolate finish what was delivered with a nice oily palate.  The carbonation was perfect for this style.  has that slight marshmellow finish mouthfeal like Kalamazoo bells stout.  As the beer warmed, the beer exibited a nice rum/cherry flavor and the maple was more apparent on the aroma.  I think i had a religions experience with this beer.  Michigan is the KING of stouts.  This could be the most under-rated beer EVER!  Strongly recomended!

Deep dark black oily pour that produces a lively dark mocha head. Decent glass lacing. The aroma is sweet molasses, roasted malt, coffee, chocolate, and light sourness. The flavor is big but not huge like the pour would suggest. Sweet malt, espresso, and mildy sweet chocolate. Hop burst at the end is a pleasant surprise. Medium body with a nice lightly sour finish. Another impressive beer from these guys.

Good brew. Black pour with a decent cocoa colored head. Creamy mouthfeel although just a tad thin in body. Has all the typical characteristics for the style. Slight roasted bitterness, hints of sweetness. Thanks to hopsrus for this one!

pours identical to the #1, their oatmeal stout.  slightly less head.  sweeter aroma, seems to have a bigger malt presence.  superior to the oatmeal stout, but it finishes a bit thinner than its predecessor.  great beer.

UPDATED: FEB 27, 2008 Bottle:  Big chocolate aroma with moderate dark chocolate and faint cocoa.  Mixed with the chocolate are roasted coffee and cream.  It pours motor oil black with a small brown head that diminishes to a thin ring along the outside edges of the glass.  The flavor stats with a light quick dose of dark chocolate that quickly fades to a roasted coffee finish with some light burnt notes.  Absolutely no sign of the 8%.  While it seems to come across a tad thin at times, its medium bodied with an oily texture and soft/creamy carbonation.

Bottle.  Typical deep black color that is like the other Dark Horse stouts.  Deep brown head fades quickly, although not as fast as One and Tres.  Deeply roasted malt aroma mingles with a bittersweet chocolate aroma.  Taste is bitter and sweet at the same time.  Very muck like bittersweet chocolate with coffee.  Really a tasty beer.  Now on to find the smoked stout and imperial stout to finish the list.

Black with rising little tan head. Chocolate espresso nose, with hints of sourness and plenty of roastiness.  Body is thick and coating, taste is strong and very roasty, damn, like a cup of thick espresso, chocolate notes and just a bit of sourness at the finish. Some hops and roasty dryness finish this one. Oh boy is this stuff good! #2 in their line of stouts.  Much better fresh from the tapper.
Dark oil look.  Roast milk flavors.  Bitter chocolate.  Nice, smooth mouthfeel.  Some vanilla bean properties as well.  Good cream stout.

UPDATED: OCT 16, 2005 this is a wonderful beer...starts with small head....nice vanilla aroma, with hints of chocolate...wonderful pour...slowly slides down the side of the glass, leaving a nice film of beer...creamy palate (one of the best in terms of palate that i have tried)..coffee an vanilla hints for flavor....great taste; viva la cream stout
Poured a black with small brown head. Sweet nutty aroma with some vanilla. Roasted fruity malt flavor with some coffee and molasses. Very smooth finish.

UPDATED: APR 7, 2007 Black, opaque, pours with a moderate brown head.  What little aroma there is sweet malt.  The flavor is roast, chocolate, molasses, sweet, and slightly fruity(prunes).  Mouth feel is creamy smooth, not a lick of acidity to be found in this beer.  Sweet finish.  Excellent Stout.

Stark black, opaque and thick set, no head, a few dark brown bubbles urge up around the edge, lace is nil as well. Aroma has a mild tone and overall low-keyed nose, has a good portion of vanilla, hazelnut, sweet chocolate, and caramel, has a thin roasty hint along with some kind of undetermined fruityness. Taste has a balancing act between mild roast qualities and sweet malts and fruits. The fruit seems like pear and slight orange which sits mostly underneath a moderate bittering black malt astringency, coffeeness, and burnt barley. The flavors are quite nice, not overly intense or brutish, it favors more of a smooth, rich smoothability and drinkability. Where as the feel and body goes, so goes the drinkability with this stuff. Sweet creamy body and bulky rich feel, slick and buttery, bold and slides right down. Finish is a partial mix of cocoa and roasty drying and tidbits of the sweeter stuff sticking.
Dark Horse seems to have their brews solidly built, as I have yet to be diappointed by one yet. The stouts are all top notch treats. As is this.

This bottled brew poured a medium sized head of brown colored finely sized long lasting bubbles.  The body was pitch black with no visible carbonation.  It had a dark malt aroma with some dark molasses noted.  The mouth feel was smooth and tingly initially with a mild tingly bitter finish.  The flavor was that of a strong dark malt.

Bottle.  Poured like liquid ebony - absolutely opaque black-brown with a thin brown head.  Aroma of burnt coffee and chocolate.  Flavor is creamy and sweet upfront followed with a bold bitterness, lingering astringent finish and a slight charcoal aftertaste.  Thick, smooth body and virtually no carbonation.

A big thanks to Brad for sending this one.  A super looking beer.  A motor oil body propped up a dark brown head of small bubbles, but its a shame that the head was MIA after only a few seconds.  Dark chocolate aroma with malts thrown in for good measure.  A bitter/sweet type of taste.  Chocolates, but also some coffee bitterness to balance it out nicely.  Truly a great stout.

This beer poured like motor oil. It formed a small sized light brown head with fine-small sized bubbles that completely dissipated. The body was opaque and uncarbonated with a dark brown hue. The nose was chocolate and malts with a sweet and chocolate taste that had a slight aftertaste. The mouthfeel was smooth and somewhat dry.

Opaque with a outstanding creamy light brown head and very good lace, beautiful! Aroma hints of roasted chocolate and dark malts, molasses, espresso, hazelnut, light aromatic hops, and dusty yeast esters. Wow, a big rush of bittersweet chocolate and a solid counter of lactic sourness (the big difference between cream and oatmeal stouts) and smokey twang. The coffee and nutty characteristics come out and play more upon the finish. The mouthfeel is lush without becoming sticky, enough carbonation without becoming flat and boring. Yes it's a sweet stout but it bring so many more "things" to the palate than most, almost an equal to Bells Double Cream IMO, recommended for all stouties! Thanks Brad for the bottle, I must now try to get a sixer.

Very motor oil looking beer with nice dark brown head. Smells like chocolate and espresso. Very bitter/sweet smelling. Awesome so far. Nice bitter flavor. Malty and burnt. Smokey oily taste and mouthfeel. Very nice beer.

Oily opaque appearance with a brown creamy head.  Aroma is sweet roasted coffee. Body is thick, heavily roasted, semi-sweet, and lightly lactic with a hint of smoke.  Finishes dry.  A decent cream stout.
rough very bitter malt tastes.  light hops  cream, i sure can't find much.  im a little unsure about this one

I hadn't sipped a Dark Horse brew since my days at Albion College, which is ten minutes from this small Marshall brewery.  I was very happy to find several recently arrived Dark Horse varieties at a nice beer/liquor establishment in Grand Rapids, most of which I have not tasted.  But enough of my reminiscing.  This is a solid, unique stout.  The very dark brown body is topped with a dark tan/light brown lasting head.  The aroma had me guessing, but I can see how it can be termed anise-like.  Definitely a strong roasted, almost smoked aspect as well (ratebeer is giving me a new positive opinion of sentence fragments).  Flavor is sweet as per style, but strong roasted, licorice, and chocolate flavors compete for attention.  The flavors do tend to compete, rather than interact, and a slightly stronger hops component would serve to balance the flavor.  Still, this Dark Horse brew manages to step outside the halls of convention, reminding me why I continue to explore the world of ale.  Recommended to fans of Arcadia's Imperial Stout.
On tap. Wonderful brown head - roasty and slightly bittersweet - limited hop components, gets a bit stick, separated? as it warms. Delicious but something is missing. Great aroma.
user_location: Łódż, Warsaw, Poland; Michigan, Ohio, USA

text: Comes on too strong for me - powerful anise and burnt toast flavours in a smooth body.

Also known as One in the trio of Dark Horse stouts.  This one and the oatmeal variety look remarkably similar - deep brown with a quick scattering tan head.  This one gets the nod for nose and flavour, with an interesting licorice accompaniment to the harder roasts and bitters.  But its best to mix the two.  Im serious!  I had the two pints poured simultaneously and when each got down to a third of a glass or so I whimsically mixed them.  The result deepened the full round sweet flavours and allowed them to better battle the bitters.  The mixture reminded me of some of the better Imperials for complexity.
pours a dark brown with a nice head, roasted malt aroma and taste, smooth, a nice stout
